# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Fix Timing Rule Violations
Fix Timing Rule Violations 
XTop supports to fix all three types of timing rule violations: transition, capacitance, and fanout. The solutions for such violations are to improve the driver capability by 
sizing or inserting buffer, or decomposing the load by splitting net.  
While fixing such violations, it does NOT care about the hold and setup timing 
violations. That is to say it is possible to bring new hold or setup violations after 
fixing. Anyway, transition and capacitance rules are checked for the driver stage to 
avoid bring new transition or capacitance violations. But XTop also offered an option 
named check_timing_margin, which will allow user to check hold and setup. It may 
be useful when there's very few transition violations and almost has no timing 
violation.  
Clock and data path violations are designed to fix separately since different policy or 
buffers may be specified. It is almost impossible for XTop to update the setup and 
hold time if a lot of eco actions applied on clocks, and XTop gives up to do this in the 
fixing process. So, it is recommended to fix violations on clock in the last step, and 
apply the whole flow immediately.  
-dff_only can be set to size only DFFs to fix transition and capacitance violations.  
By default, it only fixes violations on data paths. If want to fix violations on clock, try to run a separate iteration with option -on_clock.
Following are the corresponding commands to fix timing rule violations. For detail, 
please query the handbook or with command man in XTop. 
 
xtop> fix_transition_violations 
SYNOPSIS 
  int fix_transition_violations 
    [-on_clock | -dff_only] 
    [-buffer_list buffer_names] 
    [-methods method_list] 
    [-size_rule rule_type] 
    [-transition_target slack_val] 
    [-transition_margin margin_val] 
    [-rel_transition_margin rel_margin_val] 
    [-capacitance_margin margin_val] 
    [-check_timing_margin] 
    [-disable_report] 
    [-debug_pins pin_list] 
    [violations] 
 
xtop> fix_capacitance_violations 
SYNOPSIS 
  int fix_capacitance_violations 
    [-on_clock | -dff_only] 
    [-buffer_list buffer_names] 
    [-methods method_list] 
    [-size_rule rule_type] 
    [-capacitance_target slack_val] 
    [-transition_margin margin_val] 
    [-rel_transition_margin rel_margin_val] 
    [-capacitance_margin margin_val] 
    [-check_timing_margin] 
    [-disable_report] 
    [ debug_pins pin_list] 
    [violations] 
 
xtop> fix_fanout_violations 
SYNOPSIS 
  int fix_fanout_violations 
    [-buffer buffer_inverter_name] 
    [-max_fanout threshold] 
    [-on_clock] 
    [-disable_report] 
    [-debug_pins pin_list] 
[violations]

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Fix Wire Length Violations
Fix Wire Length Violations 
For some process, there is a limitation on wire length to avoid issues of process. XTop 
can split the nets that exceed the max length limitation with specified buffer or 
inverter to meet the constraint. XTop calculates the timing but does NOT care about 
any setup, hold or timing rule violations. That is to say it is possible to bring any 
setup, hold or timing rule violations after fixing wire length violations. Thus, it is 
important to specify a proper buffer or inverter for splitting the nets.  
Similar to fixing timing rule violations, it also gives up to update setup and hold 
timing while fixing violations on clock.  
Following are the corresponding command to fix wire length violations. For detail, 
please query the handbook or with command man in XTop. 
 
xtop> fix_wire_length_violations 
SYNOPSIS 
  int fix_wire_length_violations 
    [-buffer buffer_inverter_name] 
    [-max_wire_length threshold] 
    [-on_clock] 
    [-disable_report] 
    [-debug_pins pin_list] 
[violations]

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Fix SI Violations
Fix SI Violations 
There is actually no default constraint on SI in timing verification. It is found that the 
bigger SI effects, the bigger uncertainty will be introduced in the eco flow. To avoid 
dramatic change of SI effect, it is recommended to reduce the delta delay of SI to a 
specified threshold by sizing cell or splitting net before real timing eco.  
Similar to fixing timing rule violations, it also gives up to update setup and hold 
timing while fixing violations on clock.  
XTop also offered an option named check_timing_margin, which will allow user to 
check hold and setup.  
By default, it only fixes violations on data paths. If want to fix violations on clock, try to run a separate iteration with option -on_clock.
Following are the corresponding command to fix SI violations. For detail, please 
query the handbook or with command man in XTop. 
 
xtop> fix_si_violations 
SYNOPSIS 
  int fix_si_violations 
    [-max_si threshold] 
    [-on_clock | -dff_only] 
    [-buffer buffer_inverter_name] 
    [-methods method_list] 
    [-size_rule rule_type] 
    [-check_timing_margin] 
    [-wire_length_threshold length_threshold] 
    [-disable_report] 
    [-debug_pins pin_list] 
[violations]

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Fix Glitch Violations
Fix Glitch Violations 
There is a limitation on noise glitch height to avoid issues of process. This limitation 
cannot be set by users, it is given from preceding tool. XTop can split the nets that 
reduces these glitch heights with specified buffer or inverter to meet the constraint. 
XTop calculates the timing but does NOT care about any setup, hold or timing rule 
violations. That is to say it is possible to bring any setup, hold or timing rule 
violations after fixing glitch violations. Thus, it is important to specify a proper buffer 
or inverter for splitting the nets.  
XTop can also use size cell method to reduce glitch height. But size cell method can 
only fix violation pins with small absolute value of slack.  
Similar to fixing timing rule violations, it also gives up to update setup and hold 
timing while fixing violations on clock.  
XTop also offered an option named check_timing_margin, which will allow user to 
check hold and setup.
By default, it only fixes violations on data paths. If want to fix violations on clock, try to run a separate iteration with option -on_clock.  
Following are the corresponding command to fix glitch violations. For detail, please 
query the handbook or with command man in XTop. 
 
xtop> fix_glitch_violations 
SYNOPSIS 
  int fix_glitch_violations 
    [-on_clock | -dff_only] 
    [-buffer buffer_inverter_name] 
    [-methods method_list] 
    [-size_rule rule_type] 
    [-disable_report] 
    [-check_timing_margin] 
    [-wire_length_threshold length_threshold] 
    [violations] 
[-debug_pins pin_list]

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Optimize Cost
Optimize Cost 
XTop can utilize the timing redundant slacks to reduce the cost of design, including 
leakage power and cell area. The process to swap cells between different vt and 
channel lengths is called leakage optimization, and the process to size down cell or 
remove buffers is called area optimization. During the optimization, setup, hold and 
all design rules are considered, and it avoids to bring new violations after 
optimization.  
The default flow only commits eco operations on data path. DFFs can also be 
swapped with an extra option -dff_only. However, it will be more timing consuming 
than data path if there exists complex mutual constraints between DFFs.  
Following are the corresponding commands to optimize leakage power and design 
area. For detail, please query the handbook or with command man in XTop. 
 
xtop> optimize_leakage_power 
SYNOPSIS 
  int optimize_leakage_power 
    [-keywords name_list] 
    [-hold_margin margin_val] 
    [-setup_margin margin_val] 
    [-transition_margin margin_val] 
    [-rel_transition_margin rel_margin_val] 
    [-capacitance_margin margin_val] 
    [-effort effort_level] 
    [-group] 
    [-summarize_internal_iteration] 
    [-dff_only 
     | -enable_multithread] 
    [-auto_iteration iteration_number] 
    [-only_pins pin_list 
     | cells] 
    [-debug_pins pin_list] 
 
xtop> optimize_design_area 
SYNOPSIS 
  int optimize_design_area 
    [-remove_buffer_only 
     | -pattern str] 
    [ dff_only] 
    [-hold_margin margin_val] 
    [-setup_margin margin_val] 
    [-transition_margin margin_val] 
    [-rel_transition_margin rel_margin_val] 
    [-capacitance_margin margin_val] 
    [-effort effort_level] 
    [-summarize_internal_iteration] 
    [-only_pins pin_list 
     | cells] 
[-debug_pins pin_list]

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Write incremental SDF file.
Write incremental SDF file. 
XTOP can write an incremental SDF file during fix process, which can clean hold 
violations and tries to clean setup violations.  
Use -dir to specify the directory to save these SDF files. -
reserved_cell_delay_percentage is to control reserved delay when decreasing cell 
delay for setup.  
User can specify extra -target to keep hold clean.  
 
xtop> write_incremental_sdf 
SYNOPSIS 
  int write_incremental_sdf 
    -dir dir_name 
    [-prefix prefix_name] 
    {-hold 
     | {-setup 
        [-reserved_cell_delay_percentage reserved_delay_percentage}}] 
    [-target target_val] 
    [-anno_derate derate_val] 
[-both_timing_type]

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Analyze scenario reduction.
Analyze scenario reduction. 
XTOP can analyze all scenarios after build_timing_graph and before 
read_timing_data, by reading all GBA pin slack data, and return a dropped scenario 
list.  
User can specify -hold_top_n or -setup_top_n or both, to get wanted "topN" worst 
scenarios, which is analyzed from data in -data_dir.  
If reduce_scenario is not called, only analysis, no real reduction is made.  
 
xtop> analyze_scenario_reduction 
SYNOPSIS 
  string_list analyze_scenario_reduction 
    -data_dir path 
    [-hold_top_n hold_val 
     | -hold_coverage hold_cov] 
    [-setup_top_n setup_val 
     | -setup_coverage setup_cov] 
    [-must_include must_include_scenario_names] 
    [-factor gain_factor] 
    [-force_read] 
    [-verbose 
     [-hold_uncovered hold_limit 
      | -setup_uncovered setup_limit]]

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Clock ECO
Before timing ECO phase is started, designers assume that the CTS structure has reasonable clock skew and setup/hold WNS and TNS are workable. But sometimes, it is more efficient to repair timing on clock path than on data path. Touching one cell on the clock tree may fix hundreds of timing violations. It needs to provide another opportunity to adjust the timing by changing the clock.
XTop has provided both interactive and automatic Clock ECO solutions, which can analyze the influence of changing clock tree on setup/hold timings and margins on multiple scenarios. User can specify a reference buffer and a trace level, and run several rounds of ECO analysis until find a better solution to optimize timing (especially for the TNS).  

#### Interactive Clock ECO

xtop> clock_eco_analysis 
SYNOPSIS 
  clock_eco_analysis 
    -setup 
    | -hold 
    [-decrease_delay] 
    -buffer clock_buffer 
    [-count buffer_count] 
    [-trace_level trace_level 
     | -target_pins target_pins] 
    [-top count] 
    [-include_begin_gain] 
    [-detail] 
    [-scenario reference_scenario] 
    [-honor_dont_touch] 
    [-setup_wns_threshold setup_wns_threshold] 
    [-hold_wns_threshold hold_wns_threshold] 
The target is to fix setup or hold TNS timing violations (specified by -setup or -hold). 
Before the analysis, please specify the reference clock buffers (specified by -buffer). 
By default, clock ECO will try to add buffers on clock sinks or common points to adjust timing. The reference buffer is used for timing and margin calculation in 
multiple scenarios. The delay change will be measured by buffer typical_delay * count (specified by -count). The early/late derate is not considered.  
When the analysis is completed, it will report the top N suggested candidates (specified by -top, default value is 50). The result will be sorted by Gain_Ratio. If want to print detail pin information in each scenario, please specify -detail option. If want to see the begin gain ratio, please specify -include_begin_gain option. User can select the best N candidates to commit. Or, select the candidates whose gain ratio is 
larger than some threshold to commit.  
 
xtop> commit_clock_eco -hold -top 10 
xtop> commit_clock_eco -setup -gain_ratio 100 

#### Automatic Clock ECO

An auto-fix command has also be provided to auto-fix the setup or hold violations by applying eco operations on clock. It is a combination of analysis (clock_eco_analysis) 
and committing (commit_clock_eco).  
 
SYNOPSIS 
  fix_violations_by_clock_eco 
    -setup 
    | -hold 
    -buffer buffer_name 
    [-count num] 
    [-auto_scan] 
    [-commit_separately] 
    [-trace_level num] 
    [-gain_ratio num] 
    [-setup_wns_threshold setup_wns_threshold] 
    [-hold_wns_threshold hold_wns_threshold] 
 
xtop> fix_violations_by_clock_eco -buffer CKBUFF1 -hold 
xtop> fix_violations_by_clock_eco -buffer CKBUFF1 -setup -trace_level 4 
xtop> fix_violations_by_clock_eco -buffer CKBUFF1 -setup -gain_ratio 30

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Post-mask ECO
Post-mask ECO 
Please set the parameter eco_post_mask_mode to enable the post-mask eco mode. In 
late stage of design, user may not want to change the mask to clean the timing. Post-
mask ECO can help to do small changes to fix timing violations, by buffer insertion 
and cell sizing methods. It will only contain physical wire modification and avoid any 
placement adjustment in the layout. Post-mask ECO supports spare cell flow and ga filler flow, and both flow supports manual eco and auto eco.

#### Spare Cell Flow
For the spare cell flow, it just likes the usual eco flow, after enabling the post mask 
mode.  
 
xtop> set_parameter  eco_post_mask_mode true 
 
##### for manual eco 
xtop> insert_buffer -design {regs} {dram1/C3/U574/C1} 
{OR4D0BWP12THVT} 
xtop> size_cell -design {DIU_MDI_0_test_1} {HDMIFF/U13} {CKBD8BWP12T} 
 
##### for auto eco 
xtop  set_parameter eco_buffer_list_for_hold  {AN2 OR2 BUF2 INV2} 
xtop> set_parameter eco_buffer_list_for_setup {AN2 OR2 BUF2} 
xtop> fix_setup/hold_gba_violation ...   

#### GA filler Cell Flow
For the GA filler flow, please specify the parameter eco_ga_site or 
eco_ga_name_pattern first. IMPORTANT NOTE: If both GA site and name pattern are defined, eco_ga_site will have the higher priority. In the optimization, XTop will delete the GA filler cells, 
and insert the new cells given, and use the GA filler cells to fill the blank space.  
 
xtop> set_parameter eco_post_mask_mode true 
xtop> set_parameter eco_ga_site {gacore12T} 
xtop> set_parameter eco_ga_name_patterns {GFILL* GBUFF* GAN*} 
xtop> set_parameter eco_ga_filler_list {GFILL1BWP12T GFILL2BWP12T 
GFILL4BWP12T} 
 
##### for manual eco 
xtop> insert_buffer -design {regs} {dram1/xtop_cell_0/I} 
{GBUFFD1BWP12T} \ 
      -locations {(190.200, 94.800)} size_cell \ 
      -design {cpu} {dram_t2/C3/U392} {GMUX2ND1BWP12THVT} 
 
##### for auto eco 
xtop> set_parameter eco_buffer_list_for_hold  \ 
           {GBUFFD1BWP12T GBUFFD4BWP12T GBUFFD8BWP12T} 
xtop> set_parameter eco_buffer_list_for_setup \ 
           {GBUFFD1BWP12T GBUFFD4BWP12T GBUFFD8BWP12T} 
xtop> fix_setup/hold_gba_violations ...

#### Please note:
 only insert_buffer and size_cell methods are supported in post mask mode.
More notes for the two different flows: 
For spare cell flow:
- fix_fanout_violations, fix_wire_length_violations and optimize_design_area commands are not supported in post mask mode.
- in the buffer list parameter, not only allows buffer and inverter, but also support AND and OR cell.Currently, NAND, NOR and XOR cell are not supported.

For GA filler cell flow:
- Parameter placement_legalization_mode is not working in post mask mode.
- Supported cells include: buffer/inverter/and/or .
- By default, only allow sizing from GA cells to GA cells. In 2020.06.sp1 or later, if user wants to size between GA cell and non-GA cells, please set parameter eco_ga_cell_sizing_rule to complete.

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Flow Control
Flow Control 
The automatic flow optimizes the design by scanning the timing graph in topology 
order, thus it can complete the task with a linear complexity of design scale. And this 
is the only applicable way for modern designs that contains up to one hundred million 
of instances. However, XTop provides different effort levels to achieve higher 
optimization quality with extra timing cost. The pins are classified into several groups 
by a calculated priority for each pin, and optimized in iterations inside XTop. The 
higher effort, the more internal pin groups and iterations.  
XTop also provides a series of commands to allow user to change the criteria for 
calculating the priority of pins, known as pin rank. A better result is expected if a 
proper pin rank type is marked. These commands are mark_hold_gba_pin_rank, 
mark_setup_gba_pin_rank, mark_hold_path_pin_rank, mark_setup_path_pin_rank, 
mark_leakage_pin_rank and mark_area_pin_rank. But user should be aware that no 
single rank type can lead to best result for every case.

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### ECO Methods
#### Insert Buffer
Insert Buffer 
For fixing setup, transition, and capacitance violations, this method means to insert a 
buffer at the source of net to enhance the drive capability of cell. It is recommended to 
select buffers with good drive strength.  
For fixing hold violations, this method means to insert a buffer chain at the sink pins 
of net. The buffer chain prefers to grow toward the driver of net to avoid zigzag route 
as possible. For better effect, it is recommended to specify a buffer set with uniform 
delay distribution from both delay and normal buffers.

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### ECO Methods
#### Size Cell
Size Cell 
This method is to change the reference cell of the specified instances. Modern process 
provides variety of cells, including different sizes, vts, channel lengths and so on. It 
does not just "size" a cell in the optimization flow. But for conventional reasons, it is 
still called "size cell" here.  
XTop sizes a cell according to three principles. And it is controlled by parameter 
eco_cell_classify_rule.  
	• Library attribute, the footprint, user function class, or just the function of all 
pins. Use parameter eco_cell_match_attribute to choose the correct attribute.  
	• Nominal swap keywords in names. For different vt or channel length, 
commonly there are corresponding keywords in cell names. With this rule, cell 
can be sized between these keywords. Use parameter 
eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords to set correct keywords.  
	• Nominal sizing pattern in names. There is commonly a number represents the 
area or driven strength in cell names. With this rule, cell can be really sized 
with different size. Use parameter eco_cell_nominal_sizing_pattern to specify 
the sizing pattern.  
Normally, there is no extra limitation on sizing cell out of the principles. One 
exception is fixing hold, it is prohibited to size up to avoid unexpected area cost even 
though there perhaps exists reasonable sizing up solutions, for example, sizing a delay 
buffer up.

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### ECO Methods
#### Split Net
Split Net 
On route split net is the most efficient way to solve transition, fanout, wire length, SI 
and glitch violations. Inverter is also supported, and XTop guarantees the polarity by 
patching extra inverters.  
To get better effect, it is recommended to give a design with complete route. While 
the route of a net is not complete, XTop will try to patch it first. If it succeeds to make 
a patch, it will go on making split solutions. Otherwise incomplete fail reason will be 
reported.  
Unlike normal insert buffer, it is often unavoidable to introduce new module ports 
while splitting net along the route. XTop always tries to find the best module 
hierarchy for new buffer to minimize the count of ports to create.

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### ECO Methods
#### Remove Buffer
Remove Buffer 
This method is useful if plenty of redundant buffers are inserted during the synthesis 
process. It can be applied while fixing setup or optimizing the design area.  
While eco_remove_inverter_pair is set to true, inverter pairs are also considered to 
remove. Two inverters cascaded in the same module hierarchy are treated as an 
inverter pair.

## Automatic ECO
### ECO Methods
#### Methods Used In Automatic Flow
Methods Used In Automatic Flow

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Review The Results
Review The Results 
For every optimization flow, XTop provides a contrast timing violation or cost 
summary, a fail reason summary, and an eco action summary to users for later 
improvement on optimization policy.

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Review The Results
#### Violation Or Cost Summary
Violation Or Cost Summary 
In the optimization process, contrast statistical summaries will be printed before and 
after the optimization. It shows a overview of how much the violations have been 
fixed or the cost have been optimized in total. If you care about the changes other than 
the target currently fixed or optimized, you can summarize them with corresponding 
command manually or directly from GUI.  
Commands to summarize timing violations, leakage power and area.  
Table 4.7. Commands to summarize violations and costs 
Command 	Annotation 
summarize_path_violations 	setup and hold summary for path 
summarize_gba_violations 	setup and hold summary for gba 
summarize_transition_violations 	clock or data path 
summarize_capacitance_violations 	clock or data path 
summarize_fanout_violations 	clock or data path 
summarize_wire_length_violations 	clock or data path 
summarize_si_violations 	clock or data path 
summarize_leakage_power 	in total or every design separately 
summarize_design_area 	in total or every design separately 
 
GUI menu items to show summary: Optimization=>Violation Overview or Cost 
Overview.

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Review The Results
#### Fail Reason Summary
Fail Reason Summary 
While violations are not completely fixed, a statistical fail reason summary will be 
printed. Due to limitation of memory and performance, it is impossible to record 
down fail reasons for each candidate, and only one reason is recorded for each pin and 
each method. Though the reason is not that accurate, some clues still can be detected 
from the summary for further improvement. For example, if most of the reasons are 
failed to legalize, it indicates that the design may be too dense, it needs to release 
some area resources first. Or if most the reasons are breaking setup while fixing hold, 
it perhaps needs to adjust the constraint of setup time.  
Besides the report in the flow, you can also review the fail reason, or get related pins 
with following commands.  
Table 4.8. Commands to report fail reasons 
Command 	Annotation 
report_fail_reasons 	Report fail reason on pins. 
list_fail_reasons 	List all defined fail reasons. 
get_failed_pins 	Get pins of the specified fail reason. 
man fail_reason_name 	Get detail of specified reason. 
 
GUI menu items to show fail reasons: Optimization=>Fail Reasons.

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Automatic ECO
### Review The Results
#### ECO Summary
ECO Summary 
ECO summary is about all actions committed, including cell sized, buffer inserted, 
buffer removed, and the impact on design, including cell area and density. For 
hierarchical design, a global summary of top design or separated summaries for each 
designs can be reported by using option -recursive.

# Chapter 4. Optimize Design
## Exceptions
Exceptions 
In manual or automatic eco process, there will be some exceptions that the desired eco 
actions cannot be committed. In manual flow, it will report the reason and interrupt. 
While in automatic flow, a corresponding reason will be recorded on the scanned pin.  
Once an eco action is applied, XTOP must ensure that the netlist and placement are 
correct and legal, the timing can be updated incrementally and accurately, and the 
action can be exported with scripts to 3rd party PR tools. Otherwise, this action 
should be reported as illegal and avoided. The typical exceptions are listed as below.  
	• Netlist constraint. 
		o Module not unique. 
		o Net with IO pins. 
		o Net that connected to same nets in more than one instantiated sub 
blocks. 
		o Wrong pin direction of logical port on a net. 
		o Net cross physical hierarchies. 
	• Physical constraint. 
		o Physical placement is not ready while place legalization turned on. 
		o Dont touch pins, cells, or nets. 
		o Incomplete route for splitting net. 
		o Failed to place the newly inserted cell due to placement or routing 
congestion. 
	• Timing constraint. 
		o Conditions that unable to calculate the timing. 
	• Incomplete timing library for cells. 
	• All pins of the driver are floating. 
		o Conditions that unable to keep the timing consistency. 
	• Too large transition on pin. 
	• Too many fanouts of net. 
	• Critical SI effect. 
	• New cell is too far from net. 
		o No driver or floating pins. 
		o Multi-driven net. 
		o No gain or break timing in automatically flow. 
	• PR tool API constraint. 
		o Assign nets. 
		o Generated a feed through net in module while removing buffer. 
There are detail explanations for these exceptions in the manual of fail reasons of 
automatic flow. Please refer to the handbook or use man command to get the help on 
corresponding reason in XTop.

Start ICExplorer-XTop
Installing
The ICExplorer-XTop package is a zipped tar ball, and can be installed by just extracting it.
% tar zxvf icexplorer-xtop-2017.09-rhel5-x86_64-20171015.tar.gz 

Invoking
Before invoking ICExplorer-XTop, it needs to set correct license file first.
% setenv LM_LICENSE_FILE port@host
% path_to_your_installation/bin/icexplorer-xtop 

Command Options
Invoking icexplorer-xtop with -h, it will print all information of options.

% icexplorer-xtop -h
Usage: 
  icexplorer-xtop
    [-h | -help]            Display this information.
    [-v | -version]         Display software version.
    [-gui]                  Start in gui mode.
    [-f | -file <file>]     Source specified file.
    [-x <command>]          Execute specified command after setup.
    [-log_suffix <suffix>]  Suffix for command.txt and log.txt.
                            Log files will be command_suffix.txt
                            and log_suffix.txt if specified.  

There is also an implicit option -auto_exit. While running test flow on multiple cases in background, it will
interrupt and hang there if some error occurs while executing TCL commands, and this is not the expected
behavior. By specifying -auto_exit, ICExplorer-XTop will exit automatically while encountering errors.

Supported Platforms
Only Linux x86_64 systems are supported. The default package is for RHEL5, and is compatible with
RHEL6, RHEL7, and other equivalent Linux releases.

Name
redirect --Redirects outputs to specified file, channel or variable.

Synopsis
redirect [-append] [-tee] [ -file | -variable | -channel ] [-compress] target command_string

flag append

flag channel

flag compress

flag file

flag tee

flag variable

string target

string command_string

Arguments
-append Append the result to the target.

-channel Indicates that the target is a tcl channel name, and redirection is to that channel.

-compress Compress when writing to file. It is compatible with gzip, and does not support
append mode.

-file Indicates the target is a file name, and redirection is to that file. This is the default.

-tee Output to standard output as well as to target, same as UNIX command tee.

-variable Indicates that the target is a tcl variable name, and redirection is to that variable.

target Indicates the target name to redirect. It can be either a file, variable or channel.

command_string Command to execute. The output of the command, as well as the result, are redirected to the target.

Description
This command redirects outputs to specified file, channel or variable. It performs the same function as the traditional UNIX-style redirection operators > and >>. By default, the output is redirected to file. It can be redirect to a TCL variable or channel with corresponding option.

Note that the output command of system command, like "ls", can not be redirected by default. It needs to use TCL command exec to execute them to redirect the output. The command string must be enclosed in curly braces in order to execute successfully.

Examples

% redirect files.txt {exec ls -alt}

Commands

Name
source --Evaluate specified file as Tcl script.

Synopsis
source [-encoding coding_name] [-echo] [-verbose] [-continue_on_error] file

flag continue_on_error

flag echo

string encoding

flag verbose

string file

Arguments
-continue_on_error Ignore error and continue on.

-echo Echo the complete command lines before execution.

-encoding coding_name The encoding of the data stored in file.

-verbose Display the result of all complete command lines.

file Tcl script file to evaluate.

Description
This command evaluates the specified file as Tcl script. By default, it works with the same behavior of raw
source command of tclsh. It interprets the file in Tcl format and returned value is that of the last command.
If any error occurs, it will just stop there and skip the rest of file.

Compare to the raw command of tclsh, it is enhanced with three options for tracing the issues during
execution. The first is option -echo. By specifying this option, it will displays every complete command
lines before really executes it. The second is option -verbose. By specifying this option, the result of
every complete command lines executed will be displayed, not only the last one. The third is option -
continue_on_error. With this option, it will ignore the error and continue on the rest commands.

Description
This command gets the value of the specified parameter. It returns the value of the parameter on success.

empyrean
      

See Also

Commands

Name
list_parameter --Returns name of specified parameters.

Synopsis
string_list list_parameter [[ -fixed_string | -regex ] name_patterns ]

flag fixed_string

flag regex

string_list name_patterns

Arguments
-fixed_string Matches pattern as fixed string.

-regex Matches pattern as regular expression.

name_patterns Patterns to match parameters.

Description
This command returns the name of specified parameters. If no pattern is specified or it is empty, it tries
to return all parameters.

By default, the parameters are matched by wildcard mode. Using -regex to switch to regular expression,
or -fixed_string to match by only fixed string.

Examples

% list_parameter vendor*
vendor_name
      

See Also
set_parameter get_parameter report_parameter

15

Commands

Name
report_parameter --Reports name and value of specified parameters.

Synopsis
report_parameter [-exclude_default] [-script] [[ -fixed_string | -regex ] name_patterns ]

flag exclude_default

flag fixed_string

flag regex

flag script

string_list name_patterns

Arguments
-exclude_default Only reports parameters that have been set by user.

-fixed_string Matches pattern as fixed string.

-regex Matches pattern as regular expression.

-script Reports parameters in format of set_parameter.

name_patterns Patterns to match parameters.

Description
This command reports the name and value of specified parameters. If no pattern is specified or it is empty,
it tries to report all parameters.

While -script is enabled, it reports all the parameters with syntax of set_parameter one by one.

While -exclude_default is enabled, it only reports those parameters that have been set by users.

By default, the parameters are matched by wildcard mode. Using -regex to switch to regular expression,
or -fixed_string to match by only fixed string.

Examples

% report_parameter vendor_name
vendor_name = empyrean
% report_parameter vendor_name -script
set_parameter vendor_name {empyrean}
      

See Also

16

Commands

Name
set_parameter --Sets parameter to specified value.

Synopsis
set_parameter param_name [ -reset | param_value ]

flag reset

string param_name

collection param_value

Arguments
-reset Reset parameter to default.

param_name Parameter name.

param_value The tcl object or string representation of value.

Description
This command sets one defined parameter to the specified value. If the value is not given, it will just display
the value of specified parameter. If option -reset is specified, it will reset this parameter to the default value.

This command supports abbreviated parameter name. It does not need always to give the full name of the
parameter. It is enough just give a abbreviation that can uniquely identify this parameter.

This command will first check if the parameter name is legal. And while the value is specified, it will
check if it can be converted to the specified type, and is in the defined range. It will return false while
any step of above failed.

For point and pointf type, the format is the coordinates separated by command and enclosed with
parenthesis, like (x, y). For rect and rectf, there are two formats to specify it, one is like (x0, y0, width,
height), and the other is like ((x0, y0) (x1, y1)).

Examples

% set_parameter vendor_name empyrean
      

See Also
get_parameter report_parameter

Commands

Name
add_to_collection --Add objects to a collection, keep the original collection unchanged and return a new
collection.

Synopsis
add_to_collection [-unique] collection0 object_list

flag unique

collection collection0

collection object_list

Arguments
-unique Indicates that duplicated objects will no be added to result.

collection0 Specifies the base collection that object will be added.

object_list Specifies object list that will be added to base collection.

Description
This command adds the specified object list into to the base collection, and returns a new collection as a
result. The original collection keeps unchanged. For the object in the object list that already exists in the
original collection, it will just add it unless the option unique is specified.

It the original collection is homogeneous, this command allows the object list to be other types more than
collection. It will search the object of the same type as original collection in database. If the base collection
is heterogeneous, all the non-collection objects are ignored.

Examples

The following example shows how to add the object list to the collection.
  % add_to_collection  [get_cells u*]  [get_cells uu*]
  "u1", "u2", "uu1", "uu2", "uu1", "uu2"
  % add_to_collection  [get_cells u*]  [get_cells uu*] -unique
  "u1", "u2", "uu1", "uu2"
    

See Also
append_to_collection

Commands

Name
current_instance --Sets current working instance, and sets related commands to work in relative of it.

Synopsis
string current_instance [instance]

string instance

Arguments
instance Specifies the instance to set as current.

Description
This command sets the working instance. An instance is a cell in the hierarchy of a design. It traverses the
design hierarchy similar to the way the UNIX "cd" command traverses the file hierarchy. This command
operates with a variety of instance arguments.

--If no instance argument is specified, it return to the top level of the hierarchy.

--If instance is ".", the current instance is returned and no change is made.

--If instance is "..", the current instance is moved up one level in the design hierarchy.

--If instance is a valid cell at the current level of hierarchy, the current instance is moved down to that
level of the design hierarchy.

--Multiple levels of hierarchy can be traversed in a single call to current_instance by separating multiple
cell names with slashes.

Examples
The following example sets the working instance in the hierarchy of a design.

% current_instance top/sub/sub_sub
top/sub/sub_sub

% current_instance ..
top/sub

Arguments

Description
This command sets the libraries to use for the specified module instance. It will work recursively. All the
cells in the specified module will try to find the library cell only within the specified libraries.

The library can be just the library name, library file name or the file name with full path. The library or
file must be already linked to the specified corner. Otherwise, it will report error.

If want to clear the settings for a path, just specify an empty library list.

The following example shows how to set the bc library in fast corner to use in C3 module instance.

% set_lib_per_instance {regs/dram1/C3} {_bc.lib} -corner fast

Commands

Name
set_rail_voltage --Set rail voltage on cells.

Synopsis

mode mode ] -rail_value voltage cells

string_list corner

flag max

flag min

string_list mode

flag not_recursive

float rail_value in "(0.1,10)"

string_list scenario

collection cells

Arguments
-corner corners Specifies the corner to be set voltage.

-max Set voltage for the max condition.

-min Set voltage for the min condition.

-mode mode Specifies the mode to be set voltage.

-not_recursive Dont set value on lower cells of hierarchy cell.

-rail_value voltage The voltage value.

-scenario scenarios Specifies the scenario to be set voltage.

cells Which cells to set rail voltage.

Description
This command sets rail voltage on cells. When set on hierarchical cells, all lower cells will be set the same
value. Or use option not_recursive to stop it.

If you do not specify either the -min or -max option, tool sets value for both min/max options.

If not specify scenario/corner/mode, tool sets value for all scenarios.

If nothing was found for given scenario/corner/mode, just skip this command.

Please use get_scenario/get_corner/get_mode for wildcard scenario pattern etc.

Examples
The following example shows how to set rail voltage.

% set_rail_voltage -max -rail_value 0.88 [get_cells I_PCS3]
% set_rail_voltage -min -rail_value 0.92 [get_cells I_PCS3]

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
analyze_scenario_reduction --Analyze hold or setup violation for given timing data, and return a dropped scenario list.

Synopsis
string_list analyze_scenario_reduction -data_dir path [ -hold_top_n hold_val | -hold_coverage hold_cov ] [ -setup_top_n setup_val | -setup_coverage setup_cov ] [- must_include must_include_scenario_names] [-factor gain_factor] [-force_read] [ -verbose [ -hold_uncovered hold_limit | -setup_uncovered setup_limit ]]

string data_dir

float factor in "[0.3,3]"

flag force_read

float hold_coverage in "[0.2,1]"

int hold_top_n in "[1,300]"

int hold_uncovered in "[1,inf)"

string_list must_include

float setup_coverage in "[0.2,1]"

int setup_top_n in "[1,300]"

int setup_uncovered in "[1,inf)"

flag verbose
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-hold_uncovered hold_limit Also print uncovered hold violated pins for current selected scenarios.

-setup_uncovered setup_limit Also print uncovered setup violated pins for current selected scenarios.

Description
When this command is called, XTop read GBA slacks and rail voltage(optional) from all scenarios, and some top scenarios with worst end point violation are picked out according to user's input. When read_timing_data is called, only the timing data of scenarios in that list will be read, so memory usage and runtime will be decreased. User can call this command repeatedly with different input to get a wanted result, and use reduce_scenario to implement the behavior.

Command report_dropped_scenarios can be called to report scenarios that are dropped by reduce_scenario. If this command is called again after a valid redution, "top_n" and "coverage" will be calculated according to latest scenarios, and timing data will also be read again.

Skipped scenario setting will be honored in reduction.

The command must be called before read_timing_data and after build_timing_graph.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
analyze_scenario_reduction --Analyze hold or setup violation for given timing data, and return a dropped scenario list.

Synopsis
string_list analyze_scenario_reduction -data_dir path [ -hold_top_n hold_val | -hold_coverage hold_cov ] [ -setup_top_n setup_val | -setup_coverage setup_cov ] [- must_include must_include_scenario_names] [-factor gain_factor] [-force_read] [ -verbose [ -hold_uncovered hold_limit | -setup_uncovered setup_limit ]]

string data_dir

float factor in "[0.3,3]"

flag force_read

float hold_coverage in "[0.2,1]"

int hold_top_n in "[1,300]"

int hold_uncovered in "[1,inf)"

string_list must_include

float setup_coverage in "[0.2,1]"

int setup_top_n in "[1,300]"

int setup_uncovered in "[1,inf)"

flag verbose
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-hold_top_n hold_val Get top n worst scenario for hold.

-hold_coverage hold_cov Get worst hold scenarios to satisfy given coverage.

-setup_top_n setup_val Get top n worst scenario for setup.

-setup_coverage setup_cov Get worst setup scenarios to satisfy given coverage.

Description
User can set -hold_top_n/-hold_coverage or -setup_top_n/-setup_coverage, or both, to get a scenario list for hold or setup, or both. If "top_n" is given, the worst top n scenario will be selected. If "coverage" is given, XTop picks scenarios from the worst one, until total end point violation coverage is satisfied. If none of them are given, no scenario will be selected, so that reduction is not allowed.

knowledge.summary:

Name
analyze_scenario_reduction --Analyze hold or setup violation for given timing data, and return a dropped scenario list.

Synopsis

string data_dir

float factor in "[0.3,3]"

flag force_read

Arguments

Description
-verbose could be set to get detail info for picked scenarios, violation count and TNS of each scenario will be shown there.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
analyze_scenario_reduction --Analyze hold or setup violation for given timing data, and return a dropped scenario list.

Synopsis
string_list analyze_scenario_reduction -data_dir path [ -hold_top_n hold_val | -hold_coverage hold_cov ] [ -setup_top_n setup_val | -setup_coverage setup_cov ] [- must_include must_include_scenario_names] [-factor gain_factor] [-force_read] [ -verbose [ -hold_uncovered hold_limit | -setup_uncovered setup_limit ]]

string data_dir

float factor in "[0.3,3]"

flag force_read

float hold_coverage in "[0.2,1]"

int hold_top_n in "[1,300]"

int hold_uncovered in "[1,inf)"

string_list must_include

float setup_coverage in "[0.2,1]"

int setup_top_n in "[1,300]"

int setup_uncovered in "[1,inf)"

flag verbose
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-factor gain_factor Factor to scaling gains between scenarios, if it is set larger, it is more likely that two scenarios will be regarded as same.

Description
As this is a quick analysis, it is not guaranteed that every violation can be covered in real fix action. A factor is provided to adjust the gain ratio between scenarios, when it is set larger, two scenarios at a same violation end point will be more likely to regarded as same. The factor is 1.0 by default.

If scenario name is specified in -must_include, the scenario will always be added to list, however, if it is not contained in list by previous analysis, it will be marked a "(*)" in detail.

Name
analyze_scenario_reduction --Analyze hold or setup violation for given timing data, and return a dropped scenario list.

Synopsis

string data_dir

flag verbose
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-data_dir path The directory contains the timing data.

-force_read Force to read pin timing files specified by -data_dir.

Description
To speedup the process, pin slack files will be only read once. XTop will only read files again if -data_dir has been changed by user, or -force_read is specified.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
analyze_scenario_reduction --Analyze hold or setup violation for given timing data, and return a dropped scenario list.

Synopsis
string_list analyze_scenario_reduction -data_dir path [ -hold_top_n hold_val | -hold_coverage hold_cov ] [ -setup_top_n setup_val | -setup_coverage setup_cov ] [- must_include must_include_scenario_names] [-factor gain_factor] [-force_read] [ -verbose [ -hold_uncovered hold_limit | -setup_uncovered setup_limit ]]

string data_dir

float factor in "[0.3,3]"

flag force_read

float hold_coverage in "[0.2,1]"

int hold_top_n in "[1,300]"

int hold_uncovered in "[1,inf)"

string_list must_include

float setup_coverage in "[0.2,1]"

int setup_top_n in "[1,300]"

int setup_uncovered in "[1,inf)"

flag verbose
knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example uses scenario reduction for hold violations, and then read_timing_data.

% build_timing_graph
% analyze_scenario_reduction -hold_top_n 2 -data_dir timing_data_dir -verbose 2 of total 4 scenarios have been selected.

Selected Scenario    Hold Count     Hold TNS    Setup Count    Setup TNS ------------------------------------------------------------------------- func_fast                   854    -240.6051              0       0.0000 test_fast                   853    -232.4843              0       0.0000

Hold covered 100.00% (892/892)    Setup covered 0.00% (0/1029)

Following scenarios will be dropped after reduction:   func_slow   test_slow

func_slow test_slow
% reduce_scenario {func_slow test_slow} 2 scenarios are dropped.
% read_timing_data -data_dir timing_data_dir       

The following example analyzes scenario reduction for hold coverage over 95%.

% build_timing_graph
% analyze_scenario_reduction -hold_coverage 0.95 \n                             -must_include mode0_best0 \n                             -data_dir timing_data_dir -verbose 3 of total 5 scenarios have been selected.

Selected Scenario    Hold Count       Hold TNS    Setup Count      Setup TNS ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- mode0_worst0             13069      -4933.2574            466       -19.8865 mode0_worst1             13066      -4597.3354            139        -6.9144 mode0_best0 (*)             11           -0.35              0         0.0000 

Hold covered 99.75% (13078/13111)    Setup covered 90.00% (486/540)

Following scenarios will be dropped after reduction:   mode0_best1   ...        See Also reduce_scenario get_dropped_scenarios report_dropped_scenarios build_timing_graph

Commands

Name
analyze_tmlib_trend --Analyze all timing library cells trend loaded in current workspace.

Synopsis
analyze_tmlib_trend [[ -fixed_string | -regex ] name_patterns ]

flag fixed_string

flag regex

string_list name_patterns

Arguments
-fixed_string Match pattern as fixed string.

-regex Match pattern as regular expression.

name_patterns Patterns to match the cells, all if not specified.

Description
This command analyze all timing library cells trend in current workspace. it to check a cell's trend for
difference drive strength in different VT and channel. And this command also check cell's performance in
different process, voltage and temperature.Commonly, there are six important properties to justify a cell,
and they are represented by an uppercase letter respectively.

--A: cell area.

--L: leakage power.

--I: internal power.

--D: cell delay.

--T: output transition.

--C: pin cap.

And beside these six properties, user can use a command set_tmlib_cell_property_formula to specify
its own property to justify a cell.If you want to analyze a cell's different property in different corner, you
must specify which corner to get specified property through parameters:cell_delay_transition_corner,
cell_internal_power_corner, cell_leakage_power_corner, cell_capacitance_corner;If one of these
parameter has not been specified, or the specified corner is not in current workspace, it will not
analyze mixed corner cell trend. To analyze cell trend, user need to specify cell's drive strength
pattern and vt and channel length keywords, through parameter: cell_name_drive_strength_pattern,
cell_name_vt_keywords and cell_name_channel_length_keywords.Normally, we recognize Int
number as drive strength, if you library use float like '0p00','1p67' as drive strength, please tell as what
char represent decimal point through parameter decimal_point_tokens, otherwise we can't recognize
it.In this example you should specify 'p' as decimal point tokens.

When calculate cell's properties, there some parameters have an effect on the
result, these parameters are: tmlib_table_sample_method, tmlib_cell_evaluation_principle,
tmlib_sequential_delay_definition, tmlib_latch_timing_arc_definition,
tmlib_arc_evaluation_principle, tmlib_edge_evaluation_principle, tmlib_table_excision_depth,
tmlib_fanout_factor, tmlib_input_transition, tmlib_clock_transition, tmlib_fanout_load. After
trend analysis, user can check the timing trend on GUI. If any parameter above has been changed, user
MUST run this command to refresh the result. Otherwise, GUI just show the last analyzed result.

Commands

Name
build_timing_graph --Build timing graph from imported design.

Synopsis
build_timing_graph

Description
This command builds timing graph from design. If build_timing_graph has been conducted before
read_timing_data, then read_timing_data will skip building timing graph. If not, read_timing_data will
build it first. If timing graph has been built earlier, it won't rebuild it.

Examples
The following example shows how to build timing graph into XTop.

% source design_setup.tcl    ;# Create workspace and import design
% source mcmm.tcl      ;# Create scenario and link timing library
% build_timing_graph
                             ;# ... when timing data is ready ...
% read_timing_data...        ;# Read timing data
...        
      

72

Commands

Name
check_inst_reference_library --Check if reference library cells are valid for all cell instances.

Synopsis
bool check_inst_reference_library [ -include_instance [-truncate count]]

flag include_instance

int truncate in "[0,inf)"

Arguments
-include_instance Show instances which refers to invalid cell.

-truncate count Number of instance upper bound for invalid cell, default is 100.

Description
This command checks if reference library cells are valid for all cell instances. If any reference cell is
invalid, it will report this cell and return false. It can also show instances which refers to invalid cells,
respectively, by specifying -include_instance; the number of instances(by default 100) being shown can
be controlled by -truncate.

Examples
The following examples check if reference library cells are valid for all instances.

% check_inst_reference_library
No issue found.
1
% check_inst_reference_library
Invalid reference cells: 1
  OR2D1: 5
0
      

The following examples check if reference library cells are valid for all instances, and list out instance
names.

% check_inst_reference_library -include_instance -truncate 3
Invalid reference cells: 2
  BUFFD4BWP12T: 4
      U1/U3/buf1
      buf1
      U1/buf1
  EDFQD4BWP12T: 6
      U1/U3/B2/dff1
      U1/U3/B2/dff2
      U1/U3/B2/rdff0
0
See Also
check_inst_timing_library check_library_completeness

Commands

Name
check_inst_timing_library --Check if timing library cells are valid for all cell instances in all corners.

Synopsis
bool check_inst_timing_library [-truncate max_count]

int truncate in "[1,inf)"

Arguments
-truncate max_count A limitation of reported cell count, default is 10000.

Description
This command checks if timing library cells are valid for all cell instances in all corners. If any timing cell
is invalid, it will report this cell and return false.

Generally, it only to check if all the used library cells are valid in all corners. But once libraries are set
for some instance with command set_lib_per_instance, it needs to check instance by instance. In this
condition, the issue is reported by instance, and the item count may be large. To avoid large size of report,
an option -truncate is provide to limit the instances reported, and the default value of it is 10000.

Examples
The following examples check if timing library cells are valid for all cell instances in all corners.

% check_inst_timing_library
No issue found.
1
% check_inst_timing_library
Invalid timing library: 1
OR2D1
      

See Also
check_inst_reference_library check_library_completeness

75

Commands

Name
check_library_completeness --Check if the libraries, both reference library and timing libraries are
complete.

Synopsis
check_library_completeness

Description
This command checks if the libraries, both reference library and timing libraries are complete. Those cells
that are not complete for reference library and timing libraries, will be filtered out in ECO process.

The timing library cells must match between every two corners. This command will compare all the other
corners with the reference corner, and report all the missing, extra, and pin mismatched cells.

This command will also compare reference library with the reference corner of timing library, and report
all the missing, extra, and pin mismatched cells.

Examples
This is an example of the check_library_completeness output. cell CLXL1 and ANDXL1 has pin A in
timing library mismatched with LEF. Timing library missing a cell sub_1. There's no extra cells in timing
library. There's no mismatching between each corners.

% check_library_completeness
Check reference vs. timing:
mismatched                2
  CLXL1                   1
    A
  ANDXL1                  1
    A
missing                   1
  sub_1
extra                     0

Check timing vs. timing:
worst_cor:max             0
  mismatched              0
  missing                 0
  extra                   0
      

76

Commands

Name
check_placement_overlap --Check the overlap of the current placement.

Synopsis
check_placement_overlap [-verbose] [designs] [-ignore_blockage]

flag ignore_blockage

flag verbose

string_list designs

Arguments
-ignore_blockage Not to print cells overlapping with blockages. By default, the command reports

both cells overlapping each other and cells overlapping with blockages.

-verbose Prints a detailed report of all possible violations. By default, the command
reports only a summary of all violations.

designs Specifies the pattern list to match the design. If no pattern is specified, it means
all designs.

Description
This command checks if: 1. Cells overlapping each other. 2. Cells overlapping with blockages in the design.

It reports for fixed placement cells and non-fixed placement cells separately.

Fixed placement means COVER | FIXED instances.

In detailed reports(-verbose), each victim instance is followed by several indented aggressors(instance or
blockage-geometry). By specifying victim/aggressors, we mean aggressors overlap with the victim.

If violated instance has a halo definition in def file, we will add 'halo' after its name in the report.

Examples
The following example shows the command for printing out a summary of all violations:

% check_placement_overlap -verbose
***********************************************************
Check_overlap for design( cpu ): Report for Fixed Placement Cells
INFO #1: Fixed placement means COVER | FIXED instances.
INFO #2: In detailed reports(-verbose), each victim instance is followed
         by several indented aggressors(instance or blockage-geometry).
***********************************************************
(fixed placement) Cells Overlaps                : 2
(fixed placement) Cells Overlapping Blockages   : 1
***********************************************************
sram_1
    sram_2
    ( 68.335 210.31 ) ( 163.1 295.465 ) 

sram_2
    sram_1

***********************************************************

***********************************************************
Check_overlap for design( cpu ): Report for Non-fixed Placement Cells
INFO #1: Fixed placement means COVER | FIXED instances.
INFO #2: In detailed reports(-verbose), each victim instance is followed
         by several indented aggressors(instance or blockage-geometry).
***********************************************************
(non-fixed placement) Cells Overlaps                    : 2
(non-fixed placement) Cells Overlapping Blockages       : 0
***********************************************************
idec/U42   halo
    idec/U120   halo

idec/U120   halo
    idec/U42   halo

***********************************************************

Commands

Name
close_workspace --Close current workspace.

Synopsis
close_workspace [-force] [-purge_timing_libraries]

flag force

flag purge_timing_libraries

Arguments
-force Force to close without saving even if workspace has been modified.

-purge_timing_libraries Purge all timing libraries and release the memories.

Description
This command closes current workspace. If the workspace has been modified without saving, it will report
error unless option -force is specified.

By default, all the timing libraries are kept in memory for reusing. And it will save the time to load
timing libraries if the next workspace to create or open uses the same libraries as the previous. Option
-purge_timing_libraries can be specified to release the memories if you really want to. However, it is
recommended to exit and start a new XTop instead of using this option to avoid extra time cost.

Examples

% close_workspace
      

See Also
create_workspace open_workspace

Name
compare_slack_difference --A debug command to compare slack between xtop and user given slack file.

Synopsis
compare_slack_difference -scenario scenario_name -slack_file global_slack_file -
output_file output_file [-time_unit time_unit] [-abs_threshold abs_error] [-skip_setup] [-
skip_hold] [-only_endpoint]

float abs_threshold

flag only_endpoint

string output_file

string scenario

flag skip_hold

flag skip_setup

string slack_file

enum time_unit in "ps ns"

Arguments
-abs_threshold abs_error Absolute threshold to record difference, using xtop time unit.

-only_endpoint Only compare slack for end points.

-output_file output_file Output file to record slack difference.

-scenario scenario_name Which scenario to be compared.

-skip_hold Dont compare hold slack.

-skip_setup Dont compare setup slack.

-slack_file global_slack_file Global slack file to be compared with.

-time_unit time_unit Time unit in global slack file.

Description
This command reports the slack difference between xtop and given slack data.

Commands

Name
compare_tmlib --Compare liberty cells in timing library.

Synopsis
compare_tmlib [-name compare_name] [-source_corner corner_name] [-target_corner
corner_name] [ -cell_map_file file_name | -cell_map_keywords keyword_pair ] [[ -fixed_string
| -regex ] source_name_patterns [target_name_patterns]]

string cell_map_file

string_list cell_map_keywords

flag fixed_string

string name

flag regex

string source_corner

string target_corner

string_list source_name_patterns

string_list target_name_patterns

Arguments
-cell_map_file file_name Cell name mapping files of source and target if the source and target

use different naming rule.

-cell_map_keywords keyword_pair Keywords to match cell names between source and target.

-fixed_string Use fixed string to match pattern.

-name compare_name Compare session name.

-regex Use regular expression to match pattern.

-source_corner corner_name Source corner for comparison.

-target_corner corner_name Target corner for comparison.

source_name_patterns Name patterns of the source cells.

target_name_patterns Name patterns of the target cells.

Description
This command compares cells in the library. It can also compare cells cross corners, or just inside one
corner.

User can specify a name for the compare action. Through this name, it can reload, merge or delete compare
results. If user not specify name, it will assign an inner name for this comparison.

While the cells to compare are named with different name styles, for example, libraries from different
vendors, it needs to define the mapping rule to build the cell pairs.

--Specify a map file with a simple format: one cell pair on each line.

--Specify a map rule with keywords. For example, comparing between normal VT and low VT
cells: "AND2", "OR2", "AND2LVT", and "OR2LVT", just specify keywords like {"" "LVT"}.For
a 2-dimension keywords, please combine the keywords with separator '@', like {"LVT@20p",
"HVT@35p"}

Examples

84

Name
configure_design_definition --Configure design definition.

Synopsis
configure_design_definition -name design_name [-new_name design_name] -verilogs
file_list [-def file_name]

string def

string new_name

Arguments
-def file_name DEF file for this design.

-name design_name Name of the design.

-new_name design_name New name of the design.

-verilogs file_list Verilog files for this design.

Description
This command configures design definition. It modifies the settings of existing design. For detail, please
refer to command create_design_definition.

Examples
The following example configures an existing design by a new design:

% create_design_definition -name sub   \
    -verilogs {/home/user/date/sub.v}  \
    -def {/home/user/date/sub.def}
% configure_design_definition -name sub -new_name sub1 \
    -verilogs {/home/user/date/sub1.v} \
    -def {/home/user/date/sub1.def}
      

See Also

Name
create_corner --Create corner.

Synopsis
create_corner corner_name

string corner_name

Arguments
corner_name Corner name to create.

86

Commands

Name
create_design_definition --Create design definition.

Synopsis
create_design_definition [-overwrite] [-name design_name] -verilogs file_list [-def
file_name]

string def

string name

flag overwrite

string_list verilogs

Arguments
-def file_name DEF file for this design.

-name design_name Name of the design.

-overwrite Overwrite the design if already exists.

-verilogs file_list Verilog files for this design.

Description
This command creates design definition. Generally, a design consists Verilog files and one DEF file which
represent the logical and physical view respectively. Files for both views must be specified except that the
workspace is defined as logical only.

For a block hierarchical design, it needs to create all the design definitions from bottom up to the top
design. For a general hierarchical design with DEF files, define_designs can help to create all the design
definitions by analyzing the verilog and DEF files.

Once all design definitions have been created, it needs to check if all the sites are matched with those in
reference library. Some PR tools write a meaningless site name in DEF file in the exporting process. And
it needs to set a correct site map with command set_site_map before import designs.

If technology groups other than the default are defined while linking the reference library, it needs to
set correct technology group for the design with command set_tech_group. Otherwise, the design will
reference the default library while importing.

Examples
The following example creates a sub design with DEF file:

% create_design_definition -name sub \
    -verilogs /home/user/date/sub.v -def /home/user/date/sub.def
      

The following example creates a sub design without DEF file:
% create_design_definition -name sub1 \
    -verilogs /home/user/date/sub1.v
      

The following example creates a 2-level hierarchical design:

% create_design_definition -name sub2 \
    -verilogs /home/user/date/sub2.v -def /home/user/date/sub2.def
% create_design_definition -name top  \
    -verilogs /home/user/date/top.v -def /home/user/date/top.def
      

The following example creates an already existing design:

% create_design_definition -overwrite -name top \
    -verilogs /home/user/date/top.v -def /home/user/date/top.def
      
See Also
configure_design_definition remove_design_definition define_designs import_designs

Commands

Name
create_workspace --Create a workspace for timing optimization.

Synopsis
create_workspace [-overwrite] [-logical_only] workspace_path

flag logical_only

flag overwrite

string workspace_path

Arguments
-logical_only For logical only design.

-overwrite Force to overwrite if the specified directory is not empty.

workspace_path The path to create the workspace.

Description
This command tries to create a workspace for timing optimization. If the path does not exist, it will create
it automatically. If the path already exists and is NOT empty, it will report error, and ask user to specify
-overwrite to continue.

It will report error if failed to create the directory or the directory is not writable. On success, it will return
a string of full path to the workspace.

Examples
The following example uses the create_workspace command to create a workspace for timing
optimization.

% create_workspace /home/user/tutorial
      

The following example shows to create a workspace for logical only design. After that, user can only use
the -verilogs option of the create_design_definition command to create logical only design.

% create_workspace -logical_only /home/user/tutorial
      

If the path already exists and is not empty, use the -overwrite option can continue to create a workspace.

% create_workspace -overwrite /home/user/tutorial
      

See Also
open_workspace close_workspace

Commands

Name
define_designs --Define designs automatically with Verilog and DEF files.

Synopsis
define_designs [-force] -verilogs file_list -defs file_list

string_list defs

flag force

string_list verilogs

Arguments
-defs file_list All the def files.

-force Force to continue on even some of the specified files do not exist or are
not readable.

-verilogs file_list All the verilog files.

Description
This command creates all design definitions automatically by analyze the give Verilog and DEF files. For
a block hierarchical design, it needs to define each design from bottom up one by one. This command
analyzes all the Verilog and DEF files and creates all the definitions in the dependency order. The decisions
made by this command are all depend on the files specified, so it is always recommended to review the
created designs carefully on GUI or with command report_design_definition before importing them.

By default, if any of the specified Verilog or DEF files does not exist or is not readable, this command
will break down and report an error. However, you can skip this error by specify option -force, and this
command will keep going on execution.

Examples
The following example defines a 2-level hierarchical design:

% define_designs \
    -verilogs "/home/user/date/sub1.v /home/user/date/top.v" \
    -def "/home/user/date/sub1.def /home/user/date/top.def"
      

See Also
create_design_definition

Commands

Name
get_cells_in_region --Get cells in the specified region.

Synopsis
collection get_cells_in_region [-design design_name] [-include_hierarchical] [-
enclosed] -rect region [cells]

string design

flag enclosed

flag include_hierarchical

rectf rect

collection cells

Arguments
-design design_name Design to query the cells, top if not specified.

-enclosed The cell must be enclosed in the region.

-include_hierarchical Include hierarchical cell, leaf cells only if not specified.

-rect region Specify a rectangle to query in design.

cells The original cells to filter from.

Description
This command get cells in the specified region. It uses the coordinate system in the specified design, top if
not specified. By default, it will get all the cells overlap with the specified region. Specify option -enclosed
to get only those cells totally enclosed in the region.

If you want to get the cells in this region from a specific cell set, just specify the collection of cells as
the input of this command.

All the queried cells will be mapped to STA cells in the top design. So, some physical cells, like fillers
will be filtered automatically. And if you query in a multiple instantiated sub-design, matched cells in all
instances will be returned.

By default, only leaf cells will be returned, to include the hierarchical cells, specify the option -
include_hierarchical.

Examples
Get cells in a specified region.

% get_cells_in_region -rect ((314,306)(315,307))
% get_cells_in_region -rect "((314,306) (315,307))"
% get_cells_in_region -rect {((314,306) (315,307))}

Get cells matched with specified name pattern in specified region.

% get_cells_in_region -rect ((314,306)(315,307)) [get_cells -hierarchical *buf*]

Commands

Name
get_critical_gba_path --Create a collection of pins to imitate a path.

Synopsis
collection get_critical_gba_path -delay_type delay_type { -from from_pin | -
through middle_pin | -to to_pin } [-scenario reference_scenario]

enum delay_type in "min max"

collection from

string scenario

collection through

collection to

Arguments
-delay_type delay_type Specifies which type slack to use when trace critical path.

-from from_pin Specifies the start point when trace critical path, you can only use
one of the -from, -through, -to.

-scenario reference_scenario Only use slack data of referenced scenario to trace critical path.
If not specify referenced scenario, use the worst slack of all non-
skipped scenarios. That means, if scenario_A is skipped, then
ignore it when trace critical path.

-through middle_pin Specifies the middle point when trace critical path, you can only
use one of the -from, -through, -to.

-to to_pin Specifies the end point when trace critical path, you can only use
one of the -from, -through, -to.

Description
This command creates a collection of pins to imitate a path.

Examples
The following example gets the pins on critical gba path.

% get_critical_gba_path -to status_reg_2_/D -delay_type min \
                        -scenario func_fast
"fsr_reg_1_/CP", "fsr_reg_1_/Q", "U453/A2", "U453/ZN", "U382/B1", 
"U382/ZN", "U343/A1", "U343/Z", "status_reg_2_/D"

fix_hold_gba_violations.

    [get_critical_gba_path -to st_reg_2_/D -delay_type min \
     -scenario func_fast]

-----------------------------------------------------------

fsr_reg_1_/Q  -                     -         -         -
U453/A2       break_setup_of_driver -         -         -
U453/ZN       -                     -         -         -
U382/B1       break_setup_of_driver -         -         -
U382/ZN       -                     -         -         -

Commands

Name
get_dont_touch_cells --Get dont touch cells matched with the specified patterns.

Synopsis
collection get_dont_touch_cells [-hierarchical] [-quiet] [ -regex | -exact ] [-nocase]
[patterns]

flag exact

flag hierarchical

flag nocase

flag quiet

flag regex

string_list patterns

Arguments
-exact Uses fixed string, and disable wildcard match.

-hierarchical Searches for cells level-by-level relative to the current instance.

-nocase Makes the matching mode case-insensitive.

-quiet Suppress error and warning messages if no cells match.

-regex Views the patterns argument as real regular expressions rather than simple wildcard
patterns.

patterns Specifies the patterns used to match cells.

Description
This command gets dont touch cells matched with the specified patterns. By default, the patterns are
matched in wildcard mode, and it means all if no pattern is specified. While option -excat or -regex is
specified, the patterns are matched in fixed string and regular expression respectively, and it gets nothing
if no pattern is specified.

Examples
The following example gets all dont touch cells level-by-level relative to the current instance:

% get_dont_touch_cells -hierarchical *
      

The following example gets dont touch cells such as U62, U76 ...:

% get_dont_touch_cells -regex {U[0-9]{2}}

See Also
get_dont_touch_nets get_dont_touch_pins is_dont_touch restore_user_dont_touch
save_user_dont_touch set_dont_touch set_hier_path_dont_touch set_module_dont_touch

Commands

Name
get_paths --Create a collection of paths.

Synopsis
collection get_paths [-quiet] [-completely_conflict] [-path_names names] [ -within
within_module | -across across_module ] [-from_hierarchy from_hierarchy_name] [-
to_hierarchy to_hierarchy_name] [-delay_type dtype] [-path_type ptype] [-lower_bound
lower_bound] [-upper_bound upper_bound] [-scenario scenario] [-group group] [-
through_points through] [-start_points start] [-end_points end] [-filter expression]

string across

flag completely_conflict

enum delay_type in "all min max"

string_list end_points

string filter

string from_hierarchy

string_list group

float lower_bound

string_list path_names

enum_list path_type in "r2r in2r r2out in2out clock_gating async"

flag quiet

string_list scenario

string_list start_points

string_list through_points

string to_hierarchy

float upper_bound

string within

Arguments
-across across_module Specify the module name that path across.

-completely_conflict Searches for paths that which is completely conflict.

-delay_type dtype Specifies delay type of path, default is All.

-end_points end Specifies end point or cell patterns.

-filter expression Filter every object with the specified expression.

-from_hierarchy Specify the hierarchy name that path starts from.
from_hierarchy_name

-group group Specifies path group.

-lower_bound lower_bound Specifies path slack lower bound with unit ns, default is -1.0e6.

-path_names names Specify the path name or id list.

-path_type ptype Specifies the path type, it will return all types by default.
 The types are
- **Reg2Reg**: A path from one register's output to another register's input, typically describing sequential logic between two flip-flops.
- **Reg2Out**: A path from a register to an output pin, representing the logic that drives an output from a registered value.
- **In2Reg**: A path from an input pin to a register's input, describing the flow of data from the external world to a register.
- **In2Out**: A path from an input pin to an output pin, representing combinational logic directly connecting inputs to outputs without going through a register.
- **Clock Gating**: A path involving control signals that selectively enable or disable the clock to certain registers, optimizing power consumption by preventing unnecessary clock activity.
- **Async**: A path involving asynchronous signals or crossings, where timing may not be governed by the main clock domain and can involve metastability or timing challenges.

-quiet Keep quiet, do not report message for those wrong names while
find path by names.

-scenario scenario Specifies path scenarios.

-start_points start Specifies start point or cell patterns.

-through_points through Specifies through point or cell patterns.

-to_hierarchy to_hierarchy_name Specify the hierarchy name that paths ends.

-upper_bound upper_bound Specifies path slack upper bound with unit ns, default is 1.0e6.

-within within_module Specify the module name that path within.

Description
This command creates a collection of paths.

Examples
The following example gets the paths with endpoint status_reg_0_/D, delay_type includes max and min,
and scenario is func_slow.

% get_paths -end_points status_reg_0_/D  -delay_type all \
            -scenario func_slow
"Path_59", "Path_71", "Path_75", "Path_83" ...
      

The following example is used to skip points those slacks are smaller than the lower bound threshold value.

% get_paths -end_points status_reg_0_/D -delay_type min \
            -scenario func_fast -lower_bound -0.2
"Path_45"(0.0097), "Path_58"(-0.1271), "Path_62"(0.0405) ...
      

The following example is used to skip points whose slacks are larger than the upper bound threshold value.

% get_paths -end_points status_reg_0_/D -delay_type max \
            -scenario func_fast -upper_bound 0.005
"Path_71"(0.0012), "Path_78"(0.0008), "Path_90"(-0.0074) ...
      

The following example shows how to get paths with clock uncertainty which is more than -3.0.

% get_paths -filter "clock_uncertainty > -3.0"
"Path_14220", "Path_14231", "Path_14242"

Commands

Name
get_tmlib_cell_property --Get property of certain tmlib cell on specified corner.

Synopsis
get_tmlib_cell_property -corner corner_name cell [property]

string corner

string cell

enum property in "delay transition internal_power leakage_power area capacitance"

Arguments
-corner corner_name Indicates the corner to find cell.

cell Indicates the cell name.

property Indicates the property to get.

Description
This command gets the property of certain tmlib cell on specified corner. The cell name specified is
matched using fixing string and is case sensitive. The supported properties are:

--delay

--transition

--internal_power

--leakage_power

--area

--capacitance

For different properties, the raw data is defined on different levels, such as cell level, pin level, arc level
(timing/internal_group with related_pin attribute). About the detailed calculation,

--delay/transition/internal_power :

please refer to tmlib_cell_evaluation_principle,tmlib_arc_evaluation_principle,
tmlib_edge_evaluation_principle,tmlib_table_sample_method.

--leakage_power : please refer to tmlib_cell_evaluation_principle.

--area : a fixed floating number on cell level.

--capacitance : capacitance defined on input/inout pins are taken into evaluation based on
tmlib_cell_evaluation_principle. For sequential cells, scan/preset/clear pins are ignored. For clock
gating cells, clock gating enable/test pins are ignored.

Examples

% get_tmlib_cell_property -corner ca cell_a delay
      

See Also
tmlib_cell_evaluation_principle tmlib_arc_evaluation_principle
tmlib_edge_evaluation_principle tmlib_table_sample_method

Commands

Name
import_designs --Import the contents of verilog and DEF files into defined designs.

Synopsis
import_designs

Description
This command imports the contents of verilog and DEF files into the defined designs. Designs will be
saved automatically saved.

Once fatal error encountered, the file will be marked as failed and all its contents are ignored. At the end
of this command, it will print a brief summary of how many designs have been failed to build. The detail
parse log can be reviewed on GUI or with command report_design_file_status. Even though there is
no failed file, it is also recommended to review all the warnings and nonfatal errors with this command
to detect the issues as early as possible.

Examples
The following examples show how a 2-level hierarchical design imports:

% define_designs \
    -verilogs "/home/user/date/sub1.v /home/user/date/top.v" \
    -def "/home/user/date/sub1.def /home/user/date/top.def"
% import_designs
Setup importing tasks...done.
Begin to import 2/2 designs.
Import design 'sub1'...
Import design 'top'...
Succeeded to import design 'sub1'.
Succeeded to import design 'top'.
Open all designs...done.
Resolve design links...done.
Initialize region query...done.
      

See Also
define_designs report_design_file_status
