Commands

Name
import_power_domain --Import power domain configuration from UPF and region file.

Synopsis
import_power_domain [-design design_name] [ -upf_file file_name | -cpf_file
cpf_file_name ] [-region_file file_name]

string cpf_file

string design

string region_file

string upf_file

Arguments
-cpf_file cpf_file_name Specifies the CPF file name.

-design design_name Design to import UPF and region file.

-region_file file_name File that define map between power domain and physical region.

-upf_file file_name Specifies the UPF file name.

Description
This command imports power domain configuration from UPF or region file.

UPF command "create_power_domain domain_name -elements element_list -exclude_elements
exclude_list" is supported to describe which power domain the instance belongs to. Tool will take it into
consideration while performing the timing optimization.

It is recommended to put this command before read_timing_data.

Examples
The following example shows how to import the UPF and region file.

% import_power_domain -design TOP \
    -upf_file {/home/user/design/data/test.upf} \
    -region_file {/home/user/design/data/top.pd}
      

User is allowed to only import region file when there is no UPF file. However, an UPF file is highly
recommended.

% import_power_domain -design TOP \
                      -region_file {/home/user/design/data/top.pd}

See Also
purge_power_domain report_power_domain

Commands

Name
is_dont_touch --Return if the specified cell, net, pin or library cell is dont touch.

Synopsis
bool is_dont_touch object

collection object

Arguments
object A collection of one cell, net, or pin.

Description
This command returns if the specified cell, net, pin or library cell is dont touch. Generally, the dont touch
attribute is set by user with commands. This command will also return true if this object is set in dont
touch file while parameter honor_annotated_dont_touch is set to true.

For cell, while its library cell is set as dont touch, this command will return true even if it is not set as dont
touch. For library cells, the library name is ignored since the design might have more than one corners.

For net, it uses the same rule as set_dont_touch. The logical net segment will be mapped to top level
first before querying the dont touch attribute.

Examples
The following example returns if net n73 is dont touch:

% is_dont_touch [get_nets n73]
1
      

See Also
set_dont_touch set_module_dont_touch set_hier_path_dont_touch save_user_dont_touch
restore_user_dont_touch get_dont_touch_cells get_dont_touch_nets get_dont_touch_pins

143

Commands

Name
link_reference_library --Link reference library files.

Synopsis
link_reference_library [-force] [-format type_name] [-tech_group grp_name] files

flag force

enum format in "lef timing oa"

string tech_group

string_list files

Arguments
-force Force to load while the format changed or designs imported.

-format type_name Indicates the format of the specified file.

-tech_group grp_name A marker for reference library of different technology.

files Files to link.

Description
This command links files to build reference library. The files can be LEF and OpenAccess library
definition. And for logical only workspace, timing libraries can also be used. For LEF files, it is
recommended to put the technology LEF file in front of list though this command can identify it
automatically.

Building reference library is the first step to build the whole design. Once any design data has been
imported, option -force must be specified to modify the reference library, and all design data will be purged.

Generally, for hierarchical designs, all of the designs reference the same library and technology. For
modern designs, a top design may consist of parts with different reference libraries and technologies. And
It needs to define an independent group for each technology by specifying a unique name. The name
"default" is reserved for the default technology group. If no technology group is specified, the files will
be linked into the default group.

Once fatal error encountered, the file will be marked as failed and all its contents are ignored. At the end
of this command, it will print a brief summary of how many files have been failed to load. The detail parse
log can be reviewed on GUI or with command report_reference_library_file_status. Even though there
is no failed file, it is also recommended to review all the warnings and nonfatal errors with this command
to detect the issues as early as possible.

Examples
The following examples show how to link the reference library with different options. It is recommended
that LEF files are linked as reference library.

% link_reference_library -format lef /home/user/data/fast.lef

The following example shows how to link multiple reference libraries using technology groups.

% link_reference_library -format lef  -tech_group t40_lef  $t40_lef_files
% link_reference_library -format lef  -tech_group t65_lef  $t65_lef_files
% define_designs -verilogs $top_verilog_files -defs $top_def_files
% set_tech_group -design cpu  t40_lef
% set_tech_group -design regs t65_lef
% import_designs
      

Timing library or LEF can be linked as reference library when the workspace is logical only, but only LEF
is accepted if workspace is not logical only.

% create_workspace work -logic_only
% link_reference_library -format timing /home/user/data/fast.lib
% link_reference_library -format lef /home/user/data/slow.lef
      

The following example shows if timing files already linked, how to use -force option to load another
format file.

% link_reference_library -format timing /home/user/data/fast.lib
% link_reference_library -force -format lef /home/user/data/tech.lef
      

See Also
unlink_reference_library report_reference_library_file_status set_tech_group

Commands

Name
link_timing_library --Link timing library files.

Synopsis
link_timing_library -corner corner_name [-search_type mode_name] files

string corner

enum search_type in "min max min_max"

string_list files

Arguments
-corner corner_name Corner to link.

-search_type mode_name Search type: min, max, or min_max, default is min_max.

files Files to link.

Description
This command links timing library files to the specified corner. By default, the library is used for both min
and max analysis in this corner. However, for compatibility, this command provides search_type option
to link a library file only for min or max. Please make sure to link both min and max type for one corner,
otherwise there will be error during read_timing_data.

Once fatal error encountered, the file will be marked as failed and all its contents are ignored. At the end
of this command, it will print a brief summary of how many files have been failed to load. The detail parse
log can be reviewed on GUI or with command report_timing_library_file_status. Even though there is
no failed file, it is also recommended to review all the warnings and nonfatal errors with this command
to detect the issues as early as possible.

Examples
The following example links timing library files for the specified corner.

% create_corner slow
% link_timing_library -corner {slow} \
    -search_type min_max {./idb/tutorialwc.idb ./idb/sram.idb}
      
See Also
unlink_timing_library report_timing_library_file_status

146

Commands

Name
open_workspace --Open an existing workspace.

Synopsis
open_workspace workspace_path

string workspace_path

Arguments
workspace_path Path to the existing workspace.

Description
This command opens an existing workspace. Once a workspace is open, it is locked by current process,
and cannot be opened by any other process again.

If the process is abnormally terminated in some special situations, the workspace cannot be correctly
unlocked, and it will report error while trying to open it again. For this situation, it needs to remove the
hidden lock file ".lock" just under the workspace directory manually.

Examples
This example opens a XTop workspace in a directory named "tutorial".

% open_workspace /home/user/tutorial
      

See Also
create_workspace close_workspace

Commands

Name
read_timing_data --Read timing data.

Synopsis
read_timing_data -data_dir path [-ignore_timing_report] [-memory_saving_mode] [-
ignore_data_for_sdf]

string data_dir

flag ignore_data_for_sdf

flag ignore_timing_report

flag memory_saving_mode

Arguments
-data_dir path The directory contains the timing data.

-ignore_data_for_sdf Skip read all other data except global slack for write incremental sdf
flow.

-ignore_timing_report Dont read timing report files.

-memory_saving_mode Discard unused data when read TurboMode data.

Description
This command read timing data from files. The files are generated with the corresponding scripts from
STA tools with a pre-defined naming format. This command will match files for each scenario in the
specified directory. If all the obligated files are available, it will read in all the timing data. Otherwise,
it will report error.

When turn on memory_saving_mode and given TurboMode data, tool will discard data for unused pins.
Not recommend to adjust path slack or append other scenario's timing_report in this mode. Because
clock_pin info and timing data are lost for many pins.

Examples
The following example shows how to read timing data into XTop.

% read_timing_data -data_dir "/home/user/sta_data"
      

152

Commands

Name
read_timing_report --Read timing report.

Synopsis
read_timing_report [-pretend] [-scenario scenario] timing_reports

flag pretend

string scenario

string_list timing_reports

Arguments
-pretend Not really read the file, but put in file cache.

-scenario scenario Specified the scenario to import timing reports.

timing_reports Specified timing reports to read.

Description
This command reads timing report for specified scenario. -scenario must be specified unless there's only
one scenario.

In order to support reading timing reports of multiple scenarios in parallel, option -pretend is added. While
this option is specified it just record down the information of file. Once a command without this option
is applied, all the files will be read in parallel.

Examples
The following example show how to use read_timing_report to manually add timing report file.

% read_timing_report -scenario fast_worst \
    /home/sta_data/cpu_data_timing_rpt.txt
scenario: fast_worst
  timing_rpt  ok
/home/user/sta_data/cpu_data_timing_rpt.txt
      

The following example show how to use -pretend option to read timing reports of multiple scenarios in
parallel. Only the last command will really read those timing reports.

%read_timing_report -pretend -scenario test_slow {1.rpt.gz  2.rpt.gz}
%read_timing_report -pretend -scenario func_slow {3.rpt.gz}
%read_timing_report          -scenario func_slow {4.rpt.gz}

      

See Also
purge_timing_paths

153

Commands

Name
reduce_scenario --Reduce scenario after analyzing.

Synopsis
reduce_scenario list

string_list list

Arguments
list Scenario list to reduce.

Description
This command can be called with the result from analyze_scenario_reduction or user specified
scenarios. It will delete the scenarios in list, and once they are dropped, they can not be found back unless
create them and rebuild timing graph. report_dropped_scenarios and get_dropped_scenarios are two
commands for the reduction result.

The command must be called before read_timing_data and after build_timing_graph.

Examples
The following example reduce scenarios.

% set sces [analyze_scenario_reduction -hold_top_n 2 -data_dir timing_data_dir]
2 of total 4 scenarios have been selected.
% reduce_scenario $sces
2 scenarios are dropped.
      

See Also
analyze_scenario_reduction report_dropped_scenarios

154

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
report_annotated_timing_data --Report timing data of specified objects that read in from files.

Synopsis
report_annotated_timing_data [ -verbose | -scenarios scenario_list ] [-truncate val] [- include_skipped] { -pins name_list | -cells name_list | -nets name_list }

collection cells

flag include_skipped

collection nets

collection pins

string_list scenarios

int truncate

flag verbose
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-cells name_list Specifies the cells to report.

-nets name_list Specifies the nets to report.

-pins name_list Specifies the pins to report.

-scenarios scenario_list Specifies the scenarios to report, all if not specified.

-truncate val Truncates the objects found, zero or negative value means all.

-verbose Display verbose information or just a summary.

Description
This command reports timing data of specified objects that read in from files.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
report_annotated_timing_data --Report timing data of specified objects that read in from files.

Synopsis
report_annotated_timing_data [ -verbose | -scenarios scenario_list ] [-truncate val] [- include_skipped] { -pins name_list | -cells name_list | -nets name_list }

collection cells

flag include_skipped

collection nets

collection pins

string_list scenarios

int truncate

flag verbose
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-include_skipped Include timing of skipped scenarios.

Description
By default the timing of those skipped scenarios are shown with symbol "-" instead of real value, unless option -include_skipped is specified.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
report_annotated_timing_data --Report timing data of specified objects that read in from files.

Synopsis
report_annotated_timing_data [ -verbose | -scenarios scenario_list ] [-truncate val] [- include_skipped] { -pins name_list | -cells name_list | -nets name_list }

collection cells

flag include_skipped

collection nets

collection pins

string_list scenarios

int truncate

flag verbose
knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example reports the annotated timing data of a cell:

% report_annotated_timing_data -cells cpu/sub_1/U123 cell: cpu/sub_1/U123 Name             Value    Scenario           --------------------------------------------- setup derate     1.000    slow_worst hold  derate     1.000    slow_worst setup voltage        *    slow_worst hold  voltage        *    slow_worst (-): skipped     (*): meaningless       

The following example reports the annotated timing data of net with verbose information:

% report_annotated_timing_data -verbose \n    -nets {sub_1/n179 Net1568} net: sub_1/n179 Scenario    S_Wire_Cap H_Wire_Cap S_Wire_Res H_Wire_Res ... ----------------------------------------------------------- slow_worst  0.008      0.008      0.061      0.061      ... fast_worst  0.008      0.008      0.061      0.061      ... net: Net1568 Scenario    S_Wire_Cap H_Wire_Cap S_Wire_Res H_Wire_Res ... ----------------------------------------------------------- slow_worst  0.006      0.006      0.068      0.068      ... fast_worst  0.006      0.006      0.068      0.068      ... (-): skipped     (*): meaningless       

The following is an example of a pin report by using -include_skipped option to show annotated timing data:

% set_skip_scenarios -min -max slow_worst true Skip 1 matched scenarios:   slow_worst
% report_annotated_timing_data -include_skipped \n    -pins cpu/sub_1/U286/A pin: cpu/sub_1/U286/A Name                 Value    Scenario ------------------------------------------------- setup slack         -1.581    fast_worst hold  slack          2.513    fast_worst setup transition     0.053    fast_worst hold  transition     0.024    fast_worst max   transition     0.500    fast_worst setup cap                *    fast_worst hold  cap                *    fast_worst max   cap                *    fast_worst setup path slack    -1.578    fast_worst hold  path slack         *    fast_worst (-): skipped     (*): meaningless       

The following example shows how to use -truncate option to truncate the objects found and report a cell of annotated timing data:

%  report_annotated_timing_data -truncate 3 -cells cpu/sub_1/U* cell: cpu/sub_1/U23 Name             Value    Scenario                    ---------------------------------------------         setup derate     1.000    slow_worst hold  derate     1.000    slow_worst setup voltage        *    slow_worst hold  voltage        *    slow_worst cell: cpu/sub_1/U24 Name             Value    Scenario --------------------------------------------- setup derate     1.000    slow_worst hold  derate     1.000    slow_worst setup voltage        *    slow_worst hold  voltage        *    slow_worst cell: cpu/sub_1/U26 Name             Value    Scenario --------------------------------------------- setup derate     1.000    slow_worst hold  derate     1.000    slow_worst setup voltage        *    slow_worst hold  voltage        *    slow_worst

Commands

Name
report_design_file_status --Report Verilog and DEF files linked.

Synopsis
report_design_file_status [-only_error] [-truncate count] [-designs pattern_list]

string_list designs

flag only_error

int truncate in "[0,inf)"

Arguments
-designs pattern_list Wildcard patterns to match designs, all if not specified.

-only_error Only report error information, no warning.

-truncate count Error and warning message upper bound for each file, default is 100.

Description
This command reports status of Verilog and DEF files linked. The error and warning messages in parsing
will also be reported.

To avoid large size of report, an option -truncate is provided to limit the warning and error count of each
file. Value 0 means only report file status without any warning and error message.

Examples
The following example shows how to report the design file status:

% report_design_file_status -designs sub_design
Design : sub_design
  Verilog : succeeded
     /home/user/design/data/verilog/sub_design.v
  DEF : succeeded
     /home/user/design/data/def/sub_design.def.gz
      

The following example shows how to report the only one error message count of the top design file:

% report_design_file_status -only_error -truncate 1 -designs top
Design : top
  Verilog : succeeded
     /home/user/design/data/verilog/top.v
  DEF : succeeded
     /home/user/design/data/def/top.def.gz
    Errors   : 2
      Error(line: 8746-8751) : NET net3156: 
                  This net was not found in the existing design.

TOP: 0
+-------LEVEL_2_MODULE: 1
        +-------B_MODULE: 1
        +-------LEVEL_3_MODULE_1: 1
        |       +-------A_MODULE: 4
        +-------LEVEL_3_MODULE_2: 1
                +-------B_MODULE: 2

Commands

Name
report_design_info --Report information of design.

Synopsis
report_design_info [-recursive] [ -with_top_n count [-sort_by sort_type]] [[ -fixed_string |
-regex ] design_list ]

flag fixed_string

flag recursive

flag regex

enum sort_by in "count area"

int with_top_n

string_list design_list

Arguments
-fixed_string Match pattern as fixed string.

-recursive Trace design recursively to the leaf.

-regex Match pattern as regular expression.

-sort_by sort_type The sort factor, total area or count.

-with_top_n count Report the top n library cells.

design_list List of designs to report, empty means all.

Description
This command reports the information of current design, including the netlist and total instance count.
While option recursive is specified, it will trace all sub designs as if it has been flattened.

While option with_top_n is specified, this command will report the top n lib cells.

Examples
The following example reports the information of 2-level hierarchical design:

% report_design_info
### design: sub1 ###
Name           Count
--------------------
netlist cell    11642
total cell      18535
### design: top ###
Name           Count
--------------------
netlist cell    35456
total cell      188837
      

The following example reports the information of trace design recursively to the leaf:

% report_design_info -recursive
### design: top ###
Name           Count
--------------------
netlist cell    47097
total cell      207371
      

The following example reports the information of the top 3 library cells area in the 2-level hierarchical
design:

% report_design_info -with_top_n 3 -sort_by area
### design: sub1 ###
Name           Count
--------------------
netlist cell    11642
total cell      18535
### top 3 lib cells ###
Lib Cell       Area
--------------------
BUFX1           13124.160
BUFX4           12340.944
CLKINVX2        11556.160
### design: top  ###
Name           Count
--------------------
netlist cell    35456
total cell      188837
### top 3 lib cells ###
Lib Cell       Area
--------------------
BUFX2           1.243e+06
INVX2           1.584e+05
sub1            1.363e+05
      

The following example using -regex option to report the information of the top 3 library cells count in
a sub design:

% report_design_info -with_top_n 3 -sort_by count -regex sub\[0-9]
### design: sub1 ###
Name          Count
-------------------
netlist cell  11642
total cell    18535

### top 3 lib cells ###
Lib Cell      Count
-------------------
BUFX2         2149
CLKBUFX4      1715
INVX2         1509

Commands

Name
report_net_phy_conn --Report net physical connection information.

Synopsis
report_net_phy_conn -design design_name -net net_name [-image_file
image_file_name]

string design

string image_file

string net

Arguments
-design design_name Name of the design.

-image_file image_file_name Name of the image file.

-net net_name Name of the net.

Description
This command is used to check physical connectivity of a net. Result could be one of the following 3 types:

1). Net has no shape.

2). Net is fully connected.

3). Net is open to several parts.

If (3) occurs and option -image_file is given, a image file will be generated to illustrate the open parts. In
the image, each part will has its own color. And net pin will be denoted by a circle in the image.

Examples
The following example shows check result for net pdata[7] in design cpu:

      report_net_phy_conn -design cpu -net pdata[7] -image_file np
      Net is open to 2 parts!
      

Image np.npg will be generated to illustrate the two open parts of the net.

report_placement_constraint [-design design_name]

string design

Arguments
-design design_name Design for which to report constraint. If not given, global placement

constraint will be reported.

Description
To report user defined placement constraint for given design.

Examples
The following example reports the placement constraint of the given design. ECO Inst Max Displacement
equals 150*track_pitch.

% set_placement_constraint -design cpu \
    -max_displacement {150t 5}         \
    -max_congestion 0.9
% report_placement_constraint -design cpu
Constraint Scope:               Design cpu
ECO Inst Max Displacement:      30  Micros
Original Inst Max Displacement: 5  Micros
Max Congestion:                 0.9
      

See Also
set_placement_constraint

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
report_setup_extra_derate --Report scenario setup extra derate value for given scenarios.

Synopsis
report_setup_extra_derate [-scenario scenario_pattern] [-cell cell_name]

collection cell

string_list scenario
knowledge.content:
Arguments
interpolated from parameter eco_voltage_setup_extra_derate with priority. Only one cell is allowed to be reported at one time.

-scenario scenario_pattern Patterns to match scenarios.

Description
Option -scenario is to determine which scenarios to be reported, if not specified, derate of all scenarios will be reported.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
report_setup_extra_derate --Report scenario setup extra derate value for given scenarios.

Synopsis
report_setup_extra_derate [-scenario scenario_pattern] [-cell cell_name]

collection cell

string_list scenario
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-cell cell_name When cell is given, will try to report voltage extra derate

Description
If -cell option is not specified, the extra derate value which is set by command set_setup_extra_derate will be reported, 1.0 is the default extra derate if that command not called.

When cell name is given by -cell, XTop will look up cell's voltage and try to get derate from parameter eco_voltage_setup_extra_derate with priority. When the voltage is out of bound or parameter not set, the derate will be determined by set_setup_extra_derate.

The derate reported from this command will be consistent with the value that XTop uses in delay calculation.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
report_setup_extra_derate --Report scenario setup extra derate value for given scenarios.

Synopsis
report_setup_extra_derate [-scenario scenario_pattern] [-cell cell_name]

collection cell

string_list scenario
knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example reports setup extra derate value for all scenarios.

%report_setup_extra_derate scenario             scenario derate ------------------------------------ func_fast            1.100 func_slow            1.100 test_fast            1.100 test_slow            1.100       

The following example reports setup extra derate value for specified scenarios.

%report_setup_extra_derate -scenario func_fast scenario             scenario derate ------------------------------------ func_fast            1.200

%report_setup_extra_derate -scenario {func_slow test_slow} scenario             scenario derate ------------------------------------ func_slow            1.200 test_slow            1.200       

The following example reports report extra derate of given cell on all scenarios, where the voltage is 0.65v for fast corner and 0.55v for slow corner. So XTop reports voltage derate from parameter.

%set_parameter eco_voltage_setup_extra_derate \
                                   {(0.55, 1.20) (0.65, 1.15) (0.75, 1.05)}
%report_setup_extra_derate -cell U3/DLY1 scenario         scenario derate        voltage derate        final derate -------------------------------------------------------------------------- func_fast        -                      1.150                 1.150 func_slow        -                      1.200                 1.200 test_fast        -                      1.150                 1.150 tset_slow        -                      1.200                 1.200       

The following example reports report derate of given cell on given scenario, where the voltage is 0.65v for func_fast, and not given for func_slow. So, XTop reports voltage derate from parameter for func_fast, and derate set from command for func_slow.

%set_setup_extra_derate 1.02
%set_parameter eco_voltage_setup_extra_derate \n                                  {(0.55, 1.20) (0.65, 1.15) (0.75, 1.05)}
%report_setup_extra_derate -scenario {func_*} -cell U3/DLY1 scenario         scenario derate        voltage derate        final derate -------------------------------------------------------------------------- func_fast        -                      1.150                 1.150 func_slow        1.020                  -                     1.020       

See Also set_setup_extra_derate

Commands

Name
restore_user_dont_touch --Restore previous saved user_dont_touch pins, nets and cells.

Synopsis
restore_user_dont_touch

Description
This command restore previous saved user_dont_touch pins, nets and cells. When nothing was saved, then
nothing to do except message : No dont_touch objects were saved.

Examples
The following example set "U4" as dont touch cell and save it, then set "U5" as dont touch cell too, so
both "U4" and "U5" will not be touched during optimization. Later you can restore previous saved user
dont touch setting, which means only "U4" is dont touch cell, while the dont touch attribute of "U5" will
be removed.

% set_dont_touch [get_cells "U4"]
% save_user_dont_touch
% set_dont_touch [get_cells "U5"]
% optimize_leakage_power
% restore_user_dont_touch
      

See Also
set_dont_touch set_module_dont_touch set_hier_path_dont_touch is_dont_touch
save_user_dont_touch get_dont_touch_cells get_dont_touch_nets get_dont_touch_pins

199

Commands

Name
save_user_dont_touch --Save current user_dont_touch pins, nets and cells.

Synopsis
save_user_dont_touch

Description
This command save current user_dont_touch pins, nets and cells, then user can restore them later.

When current STA design is closed, saved data will be cleared.

When save_user_dont_touch again, the saved result will be overwritten.

The user_dont_touch is dont_touch attribute set by set_dont_touch or set_hier_path_dont_touch or
set_module_dont_touch.

Examples
The following example set "U4" as dont touch cell and save it, then set "U5" as dont touch cell too, so
both "U4" and "U5" will not be touched during optimization. Later you can restore previous saved user
dont touch setting, which means only "U4" is dont touch cell, while the dont touch attribute of "U5" will
be removed.

% set_dont_touch [get_cells "U4"]
% save_user_dont_touch
% set_dont_touch [get_cells "U5"]
% optimize_leakage_power
% restore_user_dont_touch
      

See Also
set_dont_touch set_module_dont_touch set_hier_path_dont_touch is_dont_touch
restore_user_dont_touch get_dont_touch_cells get_dont_touch_nets get_dont_touch_pins

Commands

Name
save_workspace --Save current workspace.

Synopsis
save_workspace [ -as path [-overwrite]]

string as

flag overwrite

Arguments
-as path Path to save current workspace.

-overwrite Force to overwrite if the specified directory exists.

Description
This command saves current workspace. All the designs, timing data, eco actions, user settings will be
saved into the directory of workspace. Once the saved workspace is reopened again, all the data and eco
actions are consistent except that the manual eco action cannot be undone since all check points have been
cleaned.

While the workspace is saved as another name, current workspace will keep unchanged.

Examples
The following example saves current workspace as current directory:

% save_workspace
      

The following example saves current workspace as another name or another path:

% save_workspace -as /home/user/new_work/tutorial_new
      

The following example use the -overwrite option to save current workspace if the specified directory exists:

% save_workspace -as /home/user/tutorial -overwrite
      

See Also
open_workspace

201

Commands

Name
set_dont_touch --Set the specified dont touch or not.

Synopsis
set_dont_touch object_list [value]

collection object_list

bool value

Arguments
object_list Objects to be set as dont touch or not.

value Dont touch or not, default is true.

Description
This command set the specified objects dont touch or not in the design to prevent them to be modified
during optimization process.

The objects can be cells, nets, pins, paths and library cells. It is a little special for pins since they are not
real objects in designs. It is used to control the scanning process in optimization for purpose of debugging.

In XTop, only the top net can represent the physical net. All the logical net segments specified will be
converted to top level automatically.

For paths, it means that the tool does NOT try to fix the violations on the path. So, only the pins on the
specified paths are set as dont touch.

Once a library cell is set as dont touch, it means that all the cell instances with this library cell are dont
touch.

Examples
The following example sets cells matched add_* as dont touch:

% set_dont_touch [get_cells add_*]
      

The following example sets pins on Path_0 as dont touch:

% set_dont_touch [get_paths -path_name Path_0]
      

The following example remove pins on Path_0 from dont touch:

% set_dont_touch [get_paths -path_name Path_0] 0
      

The following example sets instances with the library cell matched *BUF* as dont touch:

% set_dont_touch [get_lib_cells *BUF*]  
      

See Also
set_module_dont_touch set_hier_path_dont_touch is_dont_touch get_dont_touch_cells
get_dont_touch_nets get_dont_touch_pins save_user_dont_touch restore_user_dont_touch

203

Commands

Name
set_dont_use --Set those library cells matched with specified patterns as dont use or not.

Synopsis
set_dont_use lib_cells [value]

collection lib_cells

bool value

Arguments
lib_cells Library cells to set as dont use or not.

value Set as dont use or not.

Description
This command sets those library cells matched with the specified patterns as dont use or not. If a cell is
masked as dont use, it will be filtered from the candidate list of ECO actions by default.

Those cells that marked as dont use in timing library of the reference corner will be considered as
dont use by default. And this command can NOT overwrite this attribute to false unless the parameter
honor_timing_library_dont_use is set to false.

Please note, in automatic optimization, if user specifies -buffer_list or -buffer option, those buffer cells
will NOT be affected by this command.

Examples
The following example sets two library cells as dont use:

% set_dont_use {BUFFD0 BUFFD1}
2 library cells added to dont use.
      

The following example removes library cell BUFFD0 from dont use:

% set_dont_use {BUFFD0} 0
1 library cells removed from dont use.
      

See Also
report_dont_use honor_timing_library_dont_use

204

Commands

Name
set_hier_path_dont_touch --Set all objects in the specified hier paths dont touch or not.

Synopsis
set_hier_path_dont_touch hier_path_list [value]

string_list hier_path_list

bool value

Arguments
hier_path_list Hier paths to be set as dont touch or not.

value Dont touch or not, default is true.

Description
This command set the specified hier path dont touch or not. It has the same effect of setting the modules
of the specified hier paths dont touch.

If you want to set dont touch for whole design, just specify a "/" as the hier path.

Examples
The following example sets the objects under path alu/add_67 as dont touch:

% set_hier_path_dont_touch alu/add_67
      

The following example remove the objects in specified hier path from dont touch.

% set_hier_path_dont_touch alu/add_67 0
      

See Also

restore_user_dont_touch get_dont_touch_cells get_dont_touch_nets get_dont_touch_pins

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
set_placement_constraint --Set placement constraint for given design.

Synopsis
set_placement_constraint [ -design design_name [ -max_density max_density_value [-density_region max_density_region]]] [-max_displacement max_displacement_value] [-ip_pin_exception ip_pin_exception_value] [- max_congestion max_congestion_value] [-min_filler_width min_filler_width_value] [- readiness_check_level readiness_check_level_value]

pointf_list density_region

string design

bool ip_pin_exception

float max_congestion in "[0,1]"

float max_density in "[0,1]"

string_list max_displacement

int min_filler_width in "[0,4]"

enum readiness_check_level in "hard soft"
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-design design_name Design for which to set constraint. If not given, constraint will be set to all opened designs.

-max_congestion Set max routing congestion constraint for the design. max_congestion_value

-max_density max_density_value Set max placement density constraint for the design.

-density_region Max placement density region constraint for the design, if given, max_density_region max_density constraint will only be applied to the given region. If size of the list is 2, it will define a rectangle by lower left point and top right point; and if size of the list is an even number larger than 2, it will define a rectilinear fig by its boundary points.

-min_filler_width Set minimum filler width that can be used, value is num of sites. min_filler_width_value

-readiness_check_level Set level for placement readiness check, which by default is hard. In readiness_check_level_value hard mode, if there is any undefined cell, unplaced instance or cell with no boundary information in a certain design, then this design is NOT ready for eco placement; but in soft mode, we loosen the constraint and this design is ready for eco placement in such case.

Description
To set user defined placement constraint for given design. If any constraint is not given in this command, the correspondent constraint value for the design will be remained unchanged.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
set_placement_constraint --Set placement constraint for given design.

Synopsis
set_placement_constraint [ -design design_name [ -max_density max_density_value [-density_region max_density_region]]] [-max_displacement max_displacement_value] [-ip_pin_exception ip_pin_exception_value] [- max_congestion max_congestion_value] [-min_filler_width min_filler_width_value] [- readiness_check_level readiness_check_level_value]

pointf_list density_region

string design

bool ip_pin_exception

float max_congestion in "[0,1]"

float max_density in "[0,1]"

string_list max_displacement

int min_filler_width in "[0,4]"

enum readiness_check_level in "hard soft"
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-max_displacement Set max displacement constraints for eco inst and original inst in max_displacement_value the design, which decide the specific size of search region to find place for inserted buffer.

-ip_pin_exception true|false Due to correlation and computation effort consideration, legalization engine has internal value control of max_displacement. But for pin of IP cell(LEF BLOCK type cell), it may be far away from its boundary or be covered by large placement blockage, the area decided by max_displacement_value (decided by -max_displacement) may have no space for standard cell; to insert buffer at such pin, user can set this flag, and legalization engine will automatically enlarge search region to find place for inserted buffer.

Description
This list for -max_displacement constraint must contain exact two values, with first one being used to define max_displacement_value for eco inst and second one being used to define max_displacement_value for original inst of the design. The string can either be a float, like 5.0, which means 5.0 micron. Also, it can be a float followed by a letter t or T, like 150t, which means the max_displacement_value is 150*track_pitch, with track_pitch being the routing track pitch value of the first horizontal routing layer. By default, the max_displacement_value for the design is {100t 0}; Internally, there is a maximum constraint, the largest max_displacement for the design is {1000t 50t}. Please note, if big max_displacement_value set, it will cause long runtime.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
set_placement_constraint --Set placement constraint for given design.

Synopsis
set_placement_constraint [ -design design_name [ -max_density max_density_value [-density_region max_density_region]]] [-max_displacement max_displacement_value] [-ip_pin_exception ip_pin_exception_value] [- max_congestion max_congestion_value] [-min_filler_width min_filler_width_value] [- readiness_check_level readiness_check_level_value]

pointf_list density_region

string design

bool ip_pin_exception

float max_congestion in "[0,1]"

float max_density in "[0,1]"

string_list max_displacement

int min_filler_width in "[0,4]"

enum readiness_check_level in "hard soft"
knowledge.content:
Examples

% set_placement_constraint -design cpu -max_displacement {150t 0} \n                           -max_congestion 0.9        For design cpu, this command will set max displacement allowed of eco inst from its desired place to 150*track_pitch, with track_pitch being first horizontal layer routing pitch.

The max displacement allowed for original inst in the design is set to 0, which means legalizer will not move original inst of the design. Max congestion is set to 0.9, which means legalizer will not insert buffer into region with routing congestion value larger than 0.9.

% set_placement_constraint -design A_CORE -max_density 0.85       

For design A_CORE, this command set max placement density threshold to 0.85 for the whole design area.

% set_placement_constraint -design B_CORE -max_density 0.6 \n                           -density_region {(0, 0) (30, 30)}
% set_placement_constraint -design B_CORE -max_density 0.5 \n                           -density_region {(80, 80) (100, 100)}       

For design B_CORE, these two commands will set placement density threshold in two rect regions, with density threshold as 0.6 and 0.5 respectively.

% set_placement_constraint -design A_CORE -readiness_check_level soft        For design A_CORE, this command set placement readiness check level to soft.

Commands

Name
set_placement_spacing_label --Set placement label for the given cells.

Synopsis
set_placement_spacing_label -name label_name -side cell_side -
ref_cells ref_cell_names [ -row row_index_on_cell | -range
bottom_top_label_range_on_cell ]

string name

float_list range

string_list ref_cells

int row in "[0,127]"

enum side in "left right both bottom top", while "both" means left and right

Arguments
-name label_name Label/edge name to set.

-range Only used for bottom or top label to define range of the label on the bottom_top_label_range_on_cell cell. It is a two value list, with first one denoting left bound of the range and second one denoting right bound of the range.

-ref_cells ref_cell_names Full names of reference cells to set labels for.

-row row_index_on_cell For multi-row cell, suppose number of rows this cell occupies is
N, then value of this parameter should be one in [0, N-1], with 0
denoting bottom row(bit 1) and N-1 denoting top row(bit N).

-side cell_side Specify which side of the cell to set label.

Description
This command set label name for the given side of the cells specified by cell names.

Examples
The following example sets placement label for the given cell.

% set_placement_spacing_label -name DEL3B_L \
    -side left -ref_cells [get_ref_cells DEL3B*]
% set_placement_spacing_label -name DEL3B_R \
    -side right -ref_cells [get_ref_cells DEL3B*]
% set_placement_spacing_label -name DEL3B_Side \
    -side both -ref_cells [get_ref_cells DEL3B*]
% set_placement_spacing_label -name DEL3B_Top_Side \
    -side top -ref_cells [get_ref_cells DEL3B*] -range {0 0.09}

set_placement_spacing_rule --Set placement spacing label rule.

Synopsis

[ -adjacent_rows | -halo ]

flag adjacent_rows

flag halo

string_list labels

enum unit in "site micron"

float_list value

Arguments
-adjacent_rows Specify if it is a adjacent-row spacing rule.

-halo Specify if it is a halo spacing rule.

-labels cell_side_labels Label names of cells to set spacing rule.

-unit spacing_unit Specify the unit of the spacing range number, either site or micron.
site by default.

value Two value of the rule, first is whether can abut(0/1), second is min
sites spacing - 1.

Description
This command set placement spacing label rule for the given labels with given values.

Examples
The following example sets placement spacing label rule.

% set_placement_spacing_rule -labels {DEL3B_L DEL3B_R} {1 3}

Commands

Name
set_removable_fillers --Set those cells matched with the specified patterns to be removable during ECO
and optimization process.

Synopsis
set_removable_fillers [-append] cell_names

flag append

string_list cell_names

Arguments
-append Set removable filler in append mode.

cell_names Wildcard patterns to match the library cells.

Description
This command sets those cells matched with the specified patterns to be removable during ECO and
optimization process. The cells are matched with reference library cell name, and those cells set as fixed
or locked are not included.

During the ECO and optimization process, it will the space occupied by these fillers, and write the
corresponding commands for removing them when exporting the scripts.

Specify an empty string list to clear all the removable fillers.

It is needed to run this command between link_reference_library and import_designs.

Examples
The following example specifies some buffers to be removable fillers.

% link_reference_library ...
% set_removable_fillers {FILLX2 FILLX4 DCAPX8 DCAPX12}
Set 4 cells as removable.
% ...
% import_designs
      

The following example shows how to clear all the removable fillers.

% set_removable_fillers {}
Set 0 cells as removable.
      

See Also
report_removable_fillers

Commands

Name
set_setup_extra_derate --Set setup extra derate value for specified scenarios.

Synopsis
set_setup_extra_derate value [-scenario scenario_list]

string_list scenario

float value in "[1,1.2]"

Arguments
-scenario scenario_list It can specify one or several scenarios.

value Set setup extra derate value for scenarios.

Description
This command sets setup extra derate value for specified scenarios. it has two methods which can set
uniform derate value for all scenarios or set derate value for one or several scenarios. this value will affect
delay calculation.

If command not called, or if scenario is not covered when set, the default extra derate will be 1.0.

Derate will be overwritten if the command called a second time.

Examples
The following example sets setup extra derate value for all scenarios.

%set_setup_extra_derate 1.1
      

The following example sets setup extra derate to 1.05 for func_slow, and 1.02 for other scenarios.

%set_setup_extra_derate 1.02

%set_setup_extra_derate -scenario {func_slow} 1.05
      

See Also

Commands

Name
set_site_map --Set site map for design.

Synopsis
set_site_map [-design design_name] site_map

string design

string_list site_map

Arguments
-design design_name Design to set site map.

site_map Site map in pairs.

Description
This command sets the site map for designs. Some PR tools output a meaningless site name while exporting
DEF files. It needs to specify a site map from DEF to those in the LEF library if the sites are not matched.

The site map is given in a string list with each pair from DEF to reference library. If multiple sites have
the same size, the site map can be set only once. It won't affect the legalization. If the design is specified,
1 unit can only be mapped to 1 LEF site for the design. For multiple mappings, only the last mapped LEF
site will be taken. If the design is not specified, it will be set for all designs in the workspace.

This command must be put right before import_designs, which uses site mappings directly.

Examples
The following example shows how to set global site map for all designs.

% set_site_map "unit core12T"
      

The following example shows how to set the site map for specific design.

% set_site_map -design tst "unit core9T unit2 core12T"
      

See Also
report_site_map

Commands

Name
set_skip_scenarios --Set to skip timing of specified scenarios.

Synopsis
set_skip_scenarios [-min] [-max] scenarios [value]

flag max

flag min

string_list scenarios

bool value

Arguments
-max Skip max timing for specified scenarios.

-min Skip min timing for specified scenarios.

scenarios Scenarios to skip, matched by wildcard.

value Skipped or not, default is true.

Description
This command sets to skip timing of specified scenarios. While one scenario is set to be skipped, the
corresponding setup or hold slacks will not be taken into account in ECO flow. However, it will also be
updated after ECO to keep integrity of timing.

If no timing mode is specified, it will act as both of them are specified, and all timing are skipped for
this scenario.

Examples
The following example sets to skip min and max timing of scenario func_best:

% set_skip_scenarios func_best
Skip 1 matched scenarios:
  func_best
      

The following example removes the setting of skipping min timing of scenario func_best:

% set_skip_scenarios func_best -min false
Skip 1 matched scenarios:
  func_best
      

See Also
report_skip_scenarios

Commands

Name
set_specific_lib_cells --Set specific library cells for specified design.

Synopsis
set_specific_lib_cells [-design design_name] [ -recursive | -hier_path hier_path_name
] lib_cells

string design

string hier_path

flag recursive

collection lib_cells

Arguments
-design design_name Design to set specific lib cells.

-hier_path hier_path_name Hierarchy path name of specified design.

-recursive Trace all sub designs recursively.

lib_cells Lib cells to set, matched by wildcard.

Description
This command sets specific library cells for specified design. Once the specific cells are set, the ECO
operations will look for candidates in this set only.

By default, this command did NOT trace all the sub designs unless option -recursive is specified. An empty
library cell set means clear the settings for specified design. While no design is set, it will apply to the
top design.

-hier_path is used if user wants to set the lib cells to certain hierarchy path of given design, all instances
of current and sub hierachy will be honored, but will not trace through sub designs. It will have higher
priority than full design setting.

Examples
The following example shows how to set specified library cells for sub design.

% set_specific_lib_cells -design SUB SP*
% report_specific_lib_cells
SUB : 240
  SPND2D2B
  SPND2D4B
  SPBUFD0B
  ...
      
The following example shows how to set trace all sub designs recursively.

% set_specific_lib_cells -design cpu -recursive SP*
% report_specific_lib_cells
cpu : 470
  SPND2D2B
  ...
regs : 240
  SPND2D2B
  ...
     

The following example shows how to set specific cell by hier_path.

% set_specific_lib_cells -design cpu -hier_path regs BUFFD4*
% report_specific_lib_cells
cpu :
 regs : 3
  BUFFD4EPLVT
  BUFFD4EP
  BUFFD4EPHVT
     

See Also
get_specific_lib_cells report_specific_lib_cells purge_specific_lib_cells

tech_group Technology group name to set for the specified design.

Description
This command sets technology group the specified design. Once a design definition is created with
command create_design_definition or define_designs, it will always reference to the libraries linked
in the default technology group. If technology groups other than the default one have been defined in this
workspace, it needs to set correct technology group to reference for each design.

See Also

222

Commands

Name
set_tmlib_cell_property_formula --Set tmlib property formula for trend analyze.

Synopsis
set_tmlib_cell_property_formula formula_string

string formula_string

Arguments
formula_string Formula string to set.

Description
While doing trend analysis, sometimes user want to check if the library is reasonable or not. Commonly,
there are six important properties to justify a cell, and there are represented by an uppercase letter
respectively.

--A: cell area.

--L: leakage power.

--I: internal power.

--D: cell delay.

--T: output transition.

--C: pin cap.

Only simple operators are supported in this formula: '+', '-', '*', '/', '^', and '()'. The score formula is set to
(D+T)*(L+I+A) by default.

Examples

     % set_tmlib_cell_property_formula {(A^0.67+L+I)*(D+T)}
     

See Also
get_tmlib_cell_property_formula set_tmlib_score_formula get_tmlib_score_formula

223

Commands

Name
set_tmlib_score_formula --Set tmlib score formula for comparison.

Synopsis
set_tmlib_score_formula formula_string

string formula_string

Arguments
formula_string Formula string to set.

Description
While comparing tmlibs, sometimes it needs to make a decision that which library or cell is better.
Commonly, there are five important properties to justify the score of a cell, and there are represented by
an uppercase letter respectively.

--A: cell area.

--L: leakage power.

--I: internal power.

--D: cell delay.

--T: output transition.

--C: pin cap.

And with this formula, score values can be calculated for each cell and the whole library.

Since there is no absolute standard for every property, a relative value is use to quantize the score. For
example, while comparing cell A with cell B, the area of B is 25% larger than A, the area score of A is
always set to 1.0, and area score of B is calculated as 1/(1+0.25) = 0.8.

Only simple operators are supported in this formula: '+', '-', '*', '/', '^', and '()'. The score formula is set to
(D+T)*(L+I+A) by default.

Examples

  % set_tmlib_score_formula {(A^0.67+L+I)*(D+T)}      
      

See Also
get_tmlib_score_formula

224

Commands

Name
set_units --Set unit for length, time, RCL, voltage, current or power.

Synopsis
set_units [-length unit_str] [-time unit_str] [-resistance unit_str] [-capacitance
unit_str] [-inductance unit_str] [-voltage unit_str] [-current unit_str] [-power
unit_str]

string capacitance

string current

string inductance

string length

string power

string resistance

string time

string voltage

Arguments
-capacitance unit_str String representative for capacitance.

-current unit_str String representative for current.

-inductance unit_str String representative for inductance.

-length unit_str String representative for length unit.

-power unit_str String representative for power.

-resistance unit_str String representative for resistance.

-time unit_str String representative for time unit.

-voltage unit_str String representative for voltage.

Description
This command sets units for length, time, RCL, voltage, current or power. The units must be set before
running read_timing_data.

When setting units, resistance, capacitance and time unit must be consistency. For example, resistance unit
is kohm, capacitance unit is pf, and time unit must be ns. If user wants to change time unit to ps, will have
to change resistance unit to ohm at the same time.

Examples
The following example sets time unit as ps and resistance unit to ohm:
% set_units -time ps -resistance ohm
      

The following example tries to change only time unit, but failed due to inconsistency:

% set_units -time ps
Error: Time and RC unit not consistency.
      

See Also
report_units

Commands

Name
count_eco_actions --Count the eco actions of the specified types.

Synopsis
int count_eco_actions [-last_n count] [-types type_list]

int last_n

enum_list types in "move_cell size_cell exchange_cell insert_buffer remove_buffer insert_dummy_cell
reconnect_pin insert_buffer_chain split_load split_net"

Arguments
-last_n count Count in the last n eco actions, a number less than 1 means all.

-types type_list ECO action types to count, empty means all, default is all.

Description
This command counts the eco actions of specified types.  It only counts the manual eco actions, not auto eco actions. If no type is specified, it return the count of all manual eco,
otherwise, only the specified types. While last_n is specified, it counts in the specified range.

Examples

232

Commands

Name
exchange_cell --Exchange specified cell instance with the specified cell instances.

Synopsis
exchange_cell [-design design_name] cell cell_list

string design

collection cell

collection cell_list

Arguments
-design design_name Design for this action.

cell Target Cell.

cell_list Cells to exchange.

Description
This command exchanges the specified instance with a list of specified instances.

Simply, for two specified instances 'A' and 'B', this command will size inst 'A' to the master of inst 'B',
size inst 'B' to the master of inst 'A', and exchange their positions. For the specified instance 'A' with a list
of specified instances {'B','C','D'}, this command will size inst 'A' to the master of inst 'B', size inst 'B' to
the master of inst 'C', size inst 'C' to the master of inst 'D', and for the last inst 'D', it will be sized to the
master of inst 'A'. So does their position change.

For following situations, it will report errors.

--Any of the timing library cells of specified instances is not complete for all corners.

--The target instance is not single.

--Any of the specified instances is not unique in Verilog.

--Any of the specified instances is locked in placement.

--Any of the specified instances is connected to a multi-driven net.

Examples
The following example exchange cell regs/dram1/U180/add_buf_1 with specified cells regs/dram1/U181/
add_buf_2 and regs/dram1/U181/add_buf_3.

% exchange_cell -design {cpu} regs/dram1/U180/add_buf_1 \
            {regs/dram1/U181/add_buf_2 regs/dram1/U181/add_buf_3}
      

233

Commands

Name
insert_buffer --Insert buffer and inverter chain to buffer specified pins on the net.

Synopsis
insert_buffer [-design design_name] [-inverter_pair] [-new_cell_names names] [-
new_net_names names] [-locations coord] [-force] pin_list lib_cells

string design

flag force

flag inverter_pair

pointf_list locations

string_list new_cell_names

string_list new_net_names

collection pin_list

collection lib_cells

Arguments
-design design_name Design for this action.

-force Force to insert buffer in different power domain with buffered pin.

-inverter_pair The specified cells to insert are inverters, and will be inserted in pairs.

-locations coord Original locations for the newly created buffers, and should be the same
size of lib cell list, or double if inverter pair is specified.

-new_cell_names names Cell names for the newly inserted buffers or inverter pairs, and should
be the same size of lib cells, or double if inverter pair is specified .

-new_net_names names Net names for the newly created nets, and should be the same size of lib
cell list, or double if inverter pair is specified.

pin_list Pins to buffer.

lib_cells A list of lib cells to insert.

Description
This command inserts buffer and inverter chain to buffer specified pins on the net.

Generally, it allows to insert a mixed chain of buffers and an even number of inverters. While inserting
inverters, for compatibility with other STA tools, it is highly recommended to use option -inverter_pair to
insert them in pairs. Otherwise, it cannot write out correct eco scripts for these tools.

While option -inverter_pair is specified, the cell list must be inverters and each of them will be inserted
as pairs.

If the placement legalization is on, it will try to find correct places for the newly inserted buffers or inverter
pairs in the legalization margin. If failed, by default, these cells will be put just at the specified positions,
and it will go on updating timing. If the placement legalization is an obligation, you can just turn the
parameter placement_legalization_obligated on. Thus if any cell failed to legalize, it will report an error
and revert back.

For following situations, it will report errors.

--Any of the library cells does not exist.

--The timing library cell is not complete for all corners.

--Any of the specified is not a buffer or inverter.

--The specified pins are not on the same net.

--The net has no driver or more than one driver.

--Buffer more than one pins on a net with equivalent nets.

While inserting buffer on a net that crosses physical hierarchies to buffer a hierarchical port, it needs to
specify the design that you want to put the buffer in. Otherwise, it will be always put in the upper level.
For example, insert a buffer to buffer an input "I" of sub block "CPU".

% insert_buffer CPU/I BUFX1
 

and

% insert_buffer -design cpu I BUFX1
 

The first command will insert buffer in the top design, while the second will insert the buffer in design
"cpu".

Examples
The following example inserts 2 BUFFD6 to buffer pin dram1/C3/U574/C1 in design regs:

% insert_buffer -design {regs} {dram1/C3/U574/C1} {BUFFD6 BUFFD6}
      

The following example inserts BUFFD12 at location (45.247, 57.306) to buffer pin dram1/C3/U574/C1
in design regs:

% insert_buffer -design {regs} {dram1/C3/U574/C1} {BUFFD12} \
                -locations {(45.247, 57.306)}
      

The following example inserts INVD16 pair to buffer pin dram1/C3/U574/C1 in design regs:

% insert_buffer -design {regs} {dram1/C3/U574/C1} {INVD16} \
                -inverter_pair
      

The following example inserts 2 BUFFD6 with specified names for newly inserted buffers and newly
created nets to buffer pin dram1/C3/U574/C1 in design regs:

% insert_buffer -design {regs} {dram1/C3/U574/C1} {BUFFD6 BUFFD6} \
                -new_cell_names {eco_buf0 eco_buf1} \
                -new_net_names {eco_net0 eco_net1}

Commands

Name
insert_dummy_cell --Insert inverter or buffer on the net that contains the specified pin.

Synopsis
insert_dummy_cell [-design design_name] [-new_cell_name name] [-location coord] [-force]
pin lib_cell

string design

flag force

pointf_list location

string_list new_cell_name

collection pin

collection lib_cell

Arguments
-design design_name Design for this action.

-force Force to insert dummy cell in different power domain of pins.

-location coord Original location for the newly created dummy cell.

-new_cell_name name Cell name for the newly inserted dummy cell.

pin Pin to insert.

lib_cell The lib cell to insert.

Description
This command inserts buffer or inverter on the net that contains the specified pin.

It only allows to insert single dummy cell for single pin. All the input pins of dummy cell will be connected
to the net that contains specified pin. And among all path segments on the net, the one that makes the
distance between center of all input pins and the net shortest will be connected.

For following situations, it will report errors.

--The library cell does not exist.

--Any of the specified is not a buffer or inverter.

--The timing library cell is not complete for all corners.

--None or more than one specified pin.

--The size of lib cells is not equal with pins.

Examples
The following example inserts BUFFD1 with specified name for newly inserted dummy to pin dram1/C2/
U10/C1 in design cpu:

% insert_dummy_cell -design {cpu} {dram1/C2/U10/C1} {BUFFD1} \
                    -new_cell_name {eco_dummy0}
      

The following example inserts a BUFFD2 at location (30.200, 62.870) for inserted dummy to pin dram0/
U12/A1 in design regs:

% insert_dummy_cell -design {regs} {dram0/U12/A1} {BUFFD2} \
                    -location {(30.200, 62.870)}

Commands

Name
load_native_eco_files --Load native format eco files in timing irrelevant mode.

Synopsis
load_native_eco_files file_names [-quiet]

flag quiet

string_list file_names

Arguments
-quiet Do not output any message when dropping actions.

file_names Files to load.

Description
This command loads native format eco files without updating timing. It will report a message if eco action
is in conflict with a previous action and drop the current eco action. If legalization fails, the eco action will
be dropped or just leave the cells overlapping. The legalization fail treatment is controlled by parameter
placement_legalization_obligated.

Examples
The following example shows how to load eco files:

% load_native_eco_files { native_netlist_regs0.txt native_netlist_regs1.txt }
      

The following example shows how to load eco files without printing detail messages for dropped actions:

% load_native_eco_files native_netlist_regs.txt -quiet
      

243

Commands

Name
move_cell --Move specified cell instances to new positions.

Synopsis
move_cell [-design design_name] { -to to_coord | -delta delta_x_y } cell_list

pointf delta

string design

pointf to

collection cell_list

Arguments
-delta delta_x_y Move cell list with specified delta x and y.

-design design_name Design for this action.

-to to_coord Move cell origin to this position.

cell_list Cells to move.

Description
This command moves specified cell instances to new positions. It will first check if the instances can be
moved.

If the placement legalization is on, it will try to find a legal place around the position specified.
If failed, by default, these cells will be put just at the specified positions, and it will go on
updating timing. If the placement legalization is an obligation, you can just turn the parameter
placement_legalization_obligated on. Thus if any cell failed to legalize, it will report an error and revert
back.

For following situations, it will report errors.

--Any of the library cells of the specified instances is not available.

--Any of the timing library cells of specified instances is not complete for all corners.

--Any of the specified instances is locked in placement.

--Any of the specified instances is connected to a multi-driven net.

Examples
The following example shows how to move cell by using '-delta' option:

% move_cell -design {cpu} \
            -delta {(+38.026, +24.549)} {dram_t2/mem_reg_13__0_}

The following example shows how to move cell by using coordinates:

% move_cell -design {cpu} \
            -to {(338.337,179.483)} {dram_t2/mem_reg_13__0_}

Commands

Name
reconnect_pin --Reconnect pin to specified net.

Synopsis
reconnect_pin [-design design_name] pin net

string design

collection pin

collection net

Arguments
-design design_name Design for this action.

pin Pin to reconnect.

net Net for pin to reconnect.

Description
This command reconnect pin to the specified net.

For following situations, it will report errors.

--The specified pin is not an input pin of cell.

--The specified pin is not used as clock pin.

--The specified net is not used as clock net.

--There is no path from the specified pin and net.

--Any of the cells on the path from pin to net is not a buffer or inverter.

--Any of the nets on the path from pin to net has more than one source.

--There are odd inverters on the path from pin to net.

Examples
The following example means that pin U1/C1/I reconnect to net n253.

% reconnect_pin -design {cpu} {U1/C1/I} {n253}
      

246

Commands

Name
remove_buffer --Remove specified buffer list.

Synopsis
remove_buffer [-design design_name] cell_list

string design

collection cell_list

Arguments
-design design_name Design for this action.

cell_list Buffer or inverter list to remove.

Description
This command removes the specified buffer list from design.

For following situations, it will report errors.

--Specified cells are not in same module hierarchy.

--Any of the cells is not a buffer or inverter.

--The inverters are not cascaded in pairs.

--The specified cells are not cascaded.

--The internal net has more than one source or sink.

--Both input and output net have equivalent nets assigned or term attached.

--It will introduce a pass through net if the buffers removed.

--The timing library cell are not complete for the cell(s) to remove.

Examples
The following example removes 2 buffers from design cpu:

% remove_buffer -design {cpu} \
  {dram_t2/ice2_cell_8 dram_t2/ice2_cell_7 dram_t2/ice2_cell_6}
      

247

Commands

Name
report_cell_classification --Report library cell classification.

Synopsis
report_cell_classification [ -by_attribute | -by_swap_keywords | -by_sizing_pattern ]

flag by_attribute

flag by_sizing_pattern

flag by_swap_keywords

Arguments
-by_attribute Cell classified by attribute defined by eco_cell_match_attribute.

-by_sizing_pattern Cell classified by eco_cell_nominal_sizing_pattern.

-by_swap_keywords Cell classified by eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords.

Description
This command reports library cell classification. Library cells can be grouped by defined attribute, or
swap keywords, or sizing pattern. Only matched cells within same group can be swapped or sized during
optimization.

Please note, eco_buffer_group setting could affect the classification result.

Examples
The following example displays a report of the cell classification by attribute.

% report_cell_classification -by_attribute
Classify by: footprint
an2d1 : 8
  AN2D0BX2T  AN2D1BX4T ...
invd1 : 16
...

% set_parameter eco_cell_match_attribute {pin_function}
% report_cell_classification -by_attribute
Classify by: pin_function
A1=;A2=;A3=;A4=;Z=(((A1 A2) A3) A4); : 6
  AN4D0X12T  AN4D1X12T  AN4D2X12T  AN4D4X12T  AN4D8X12T  AN4XD1X12T
...
      

The following example displays a report of the cell classification by sizing pattern.

% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_sizing_pattern {X([0-9]+)T}

% report_cell_classification -by_sizing_pattern
Pattern: 'X([0-9]+)T'
AN2DX12T: 5
  AN2D8X12T  AN2D4X12T  AN2D2X12T  AN2D1X12T  AN2D0X12T
AN3DX12T: 5
  AN3D8X12T  AN3D4X12T  AN3D2X12T  AN3D1X12T  AN3D0X12T
...
      
The following example displays a report of the cell classification by swap keywords.

% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords {LVT HVT}
% report_cell_classification -by_swap_keywords
Keywords: 'LVT'  'HVT'
ADDFX1: 2
  ADDFX1LVT  ADDFX1HVT
...
      

See Also
eco_cell_match_attribute eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords eco_cell_nominal_sizing_pattern
eco_buffer_group report_matched_cells

Commands

Name
report_eco_actions --Report eco actions of the specified range and types.

Synopsis
report_eco_actions [-last_n count] [-types type_list] [-top_n count] [-sort_by
sort_type]

int last_n

enum sort_by in "count area"

int top_n in "[0,inf)"

enum_list types in "move_cell size_cell exchange_cell insert_buffer remove_buffer insert_dummy_cell
reconnect_pin insert_buffer_chain split_load split_net"

Arguments
-last_n count Report in the last n eco actions, a number less than 1 means all.

-sort_by sort_type The sort factor, can be increased cell count, or area, default is area.

-top_n count Top n in descending order of specified sort type.

-types type_list ECO action types to report, empty means all, default is all.

Description
This command reports eco actions of the specified range and types. While top_n is specified, it will report
the top n actions in the specified action list in the descending order of the specified sorting type.

Examples
The following example reports the last 10 size_cell actions and sort the top 5 actions by area.

% report_eco_actions -last_n 10 -types size_cell \
                     -top_n 7 -sort_by area
size cell
design    : cpu
cell name : regs/dram1/C3/U454
original  : INVD1BTH
current   : INVD8BTH

size cell
design    : cpu
cell name : regs/dram1/U149/add_buf_2
original  : BUFFD0BTH
current   : BUFFD6BTH
...

Commands

Name
report_matched_cells --Report matched library cells for the specified cell.

Synopsis
report_matched_cells [ -by_attribute | -by_swap_keywords | -by_sizing_pattern ] cell_name

flag by_attribute

flag by_sizing_pattern

flag by_swap_keywords

string cell_name

Arguments
-by_attribute Cell classified by attribute defined by eco_cell_match_attribute.

-by_sizing_pattern Cell classified by eco_cell_nominal_sizing_pattern.

-by_swap_keywords Cell classified by eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords.

cell_name Cell name to get matched cells.

Description
This command reports matched library cells for the specified cell. Library cells can be grouped by defined
attribute, or swap keywords, or sizing pattern. Only matched cells within same group can be swapped or
sized during optimization.

Please note, eco_buffer_group setting could affect the classification result.

Examples
The following example reports the library cells in the same group of specified cell by attribute.

% report_matched_cells -by_attribute IOA21X4THVT
Matched cells (self included): 8
  IOA21X0T
  IOA21X0THVT
  IOA21X1T
  IOA21X1THVT
  IOA21X2T
  IOA21X2THVT
  IOA21X4T
  IOA21X4THVT
      

See Also
eco_cell_match_attribute eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords eco_cell_nominal_sizing_pattern
eco_buffer_group report_cell_classification

251

Commands

Name
size_cell --Size specified cell instances to the specified cell.

Synopsis
size_cell [-design design_name] [-location coord...] cell_list lib_cell

string design

pointf location

collection cell_list

collection lib_cell

Arguments
-design design_name Design for this action.

-location... coord Location for the cell.

cell_list Cells to size.

lib_cell Library cell to size to.

Description
This command sizes the specified instances to the specified cell. It will first check if the specified instances
can be changed, and the specified master is legal.

If the placement legalization is on, it will try to find a correct place for the changed cell in the
legalization margin. If failed, by default, these cells will be put just at the specified positions, and it will
go on updating timing. If the placement legalization is an obligation, you can just turn the parameter
placement_legalization_obligated on. Thus if any cell failed to legalize, it will report an error and revert
back.

For following situations, it will report errors.

--Any of the library cells of the specified instances is not available.

--Any of the timing library cells of specified instances is not complete for all corners.

--The library for the specified cell is not available.

--The timing library for the specified cell is not complete for all corners.

--Any of the specified instances is not unique in Verilog.

--Any of the specified instances is locked in placement.

--Any of the specified instances is connected to a multi-driven net.

--Function of the specified lib cell mismatches with original.

The following example size regs/dram1/U181/add_buf_4 to BUFFD12BTH, with user specified location.

% size_cell -design {cpu} -location {(20.772, 179.597)} \
            {regs/dram1/U181/add_buf_4} {BUFFD12BTH}

Commands

Name
split_load --Split loads of net into specified groups.

Synopsis
split_load [-design design_name] [-inverter_pair] [-new_cell_names names...] [-new_net_names
names...] [-locations coord...] -pin_group pin_list... -lib_cell cell_name

string design

flag inverter_pair

collection lib_cell

pointf_list locations

string_list new_cell_names

string_list new_net_names

collection pin_group

Arguments
-design design_name Design for this action.

-inverter_pair The specified cell to insert is inverter, and will be inserted in pair.

-lib_cell cell_name Lib cell for the buffer.

-locations... coord Original location for the newly inserted buffer, and should be in
pairs for inverters.

-new_cell_names... names Cell name for the newly inserted buffer, and should be in pairs for
inverters.

-new_net_names... names Net name for the newly inserted buffer, and should be in pairs for
inverters.

-pin_group... pin_list One group of pins to buffer.

Description
This command split net into specified groups.

It optimizes fanout. Since large fanout can cause other violations like transition violations, it may helps to fix these violations.

If the placement legalization is on, it will try to find correct places for each newly created buffer or inverter
pair in legalization margin. If failed, by default, these cells will be put just at the specified positions, and it
will go on updating timing. If the placement legalization is an obligation, you can just turn the parameter
placement_legalization_obligated on. Thus if any cell failed to legalize, it will report an error and revert
back.

For following situations, it will report errors.

--The library cell does not exist.

--The timing library cell is not complete for all corners.

--Specified is not a buffer or inverter.

--The specified pins are not on the same net.

--The net has no driver or more than one driver.

--The net has equivalent net.

Examples
The following example splits 3 loads into two pin_groups with user specified locations.

% split_load -design {top} -lib_cell {BUFD8BTH} \
             -pin_group {U1/instA/I U1/instB/I} \
             -locations {(882.602, 3183.335)}   \
             -pin_group {U0/instC/I}            \
             -locations {(1140.736, 3165.997)}

Commands

Name
split_net --Split net into several segments by specified rule.

Synopsis
split_net [-design design_name] [-scenario scenario_name] net -lib_cell cell_name -rule
split_rule -segment split_segment_count

string design

collection lib_cell

enum rule in "wire_length cap"

string scenario

int segment in "[2,inf)"

collection net

Arguments
-design design_name Design for this action.

-lib_cell cell_name Lib cell for the buffer.

-rule split_rule Split rule: wire_length, cap.

-scenario scenario_name Scenario for calculating capacitance.

-segment split_segment_count Split the specified net into n segments.

net Net to split.

Description
Split net is an efficient method to fix transition violations for long nets, especially for long nets which do
not have branches or have very few short branches.

This command split net into several segments by wire length or capacitance with specified buffer or
inverter in manual eco (different in auto eco). For each segment, the wire length or total capacitance should be the same. However, for nets
which have many branches, due to the tree structure of net, the segment length or capacitance may be less
than the average value, and the segment count may be more than the specified count. Also, if inverter is
used to split net, extra inverters may be inserted to keep the correct polarity.

If the placement legalization is on, it will try to find correct places for each newly created buffer or inverter
in legalization margin. If failed, by default, these cells will be put just at the specified positions, and it
will go on updating timing. If the placement legalization is an obligation, you can just turn the parameter
placement_legalization_obligated on. Thus if any cell failed to legalize, it will report an error and revert
back.

For following situations, it will report errors.

--The library cell does not exist.

--The timing library cell is not complete for all corners.

--Specified is not a buffer or inverter.

--The net has no driver or more than one driver.

--The net has equivalent net.

--The net has no complete route.

--The net has been touched by previous eco actions.

Examples
The following example uses the buffer to split one net into 3 segments by wire length.

% split_net -design {cpu} -lib_cell {BUFFX4} -segment 3 \
            -rule wire_length {sub/C32/n246}
      

The following example uses the buffer to split one net into 5 segments by capacitance.

% split_net -design {cpu} -lib_cell {BUFFX6} -segment 5 \
            -rule cap -scenario func_fast {n42}

This command summarizes the information of capacitance violations in design. It will output the violation count, worst slack, and total negative slack.

While pins are specified, it will only summarize the pins in the pin list.

Arguments

-with_delta Report delta to the reference if possible.

-with_reference Report the reference in the same table if exists.

Description
While the option -with_delta or -with_reference is on, it will try to find the matched reference record, and report the difference according to the reference value of it. While option -as_reference is on, current summary will be set as reference.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-io_only Only summarize those endpoints on io paths.

-r2r_only Only summarize those endpoints on r2r paths.

Description
By default, all pins are taken into account in the summary. Also you can summarize the violations related to io or internal r2r paths respectively by specifying option -io_only or -r2r_only. However, the criterion to identify whether a pin is on io or internal path is not well defined, and XTop just follows the timing data dumped from STA tools.
