knowledge.content:
Arguments
-exclude_dont_touch Do not take those pins marked as dont touch into account.

Description
While option -exclude_dont_touch is specified, those endpoints that already marked as dont touch will be ignored in the summary. Notice that it only takes the dont touch attribute on pin, and does NOT care about cells and nets. If any doubt on this, please use command is_dont_touch to verify.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
summarize_capacitance_violations --Summarize the information of capacitance violations in design.

Synopsis
summarize_capacitance_violations [-as_reference] [-with_delta] [-with_reference] [-clock] [-data_path] [ -r2r_only | -io_only ] [-exclude_dont_touch] [-with_distribution] [ -with_top_n count [- with_fail_reason]] [pin_list]

flag as_reference

flag clock

flag data_path

flag exclude_dont_touch

flag io_only

flag r2r_only

flag with_delta

flag with_distribution

flag with_fail_reason

flag with_reference

int with_top_n in "[1,inf)"

collection pin_list
knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example summarizes the information of capacitance violations and set current summary as a reference for later summary:

% summarize_capacitance_violations -as_reference ### capacitance summary ### Scenario        Count     Worst       TNS ------------------------------------------ total             135    -1.217    -7.737   func_best       122    -1.217    -7.519   func_worst      127    -1.080    -7.402       

The following example summarizes the information of capacitance violations on clock network:

% summarize_capacitance_violations -clock       

The following example summarizes the information of capacitance violations on data path:

% summarize_capacitance_violations -data_path

The following example summarizes the information of capacitance violations and reports the top 5 worst endpoints:

% summarize_capacitance_violations -with_top_n 5 ### capacitance summary ### Scenario        Count     Worst       TNS ------------------------------------------ total             135    -1.217    -7.737   func_best       122    -1.217    -7.519   func_worst      127    -1.080    -7.402 ### capacitance top 5 endpoints ###  Slack    Scenario     Value    Constraint    Name
-------------------------------------------------------------- -1.217    func_best    2.311         0.095    U316/Z -0.786    func_best    1.965         0.190    U395/Z -0.568    func_best    0.215         0.047    clk_gen_u0/U4/Z -0.439    func_best    0.329         0.190    U325/ZN -0.122    func_best    0.168         0.046    regs/U9/ZN       

The following example summarizes the information of capacitance violations on data path with reference and delta value:

% summarize_capacitance_violations -with_reference -with_delta \n                                   -data_path ### capacitance summary ### Scenario  Count Count0 D_Count    Worst  Worst0  D_Worst   TNS  ... ------------------------------------------------------------- total         1   131  -130     | -0.005 -0.139  +0.134  | -0.005 ...   func_best   1   118  -117     | -0.002 -0.139  +0.138  | -0.002 ...   func_worst  1   123  -122     | -0.005 -0.135  +0.130  | -0.005 ...

Commands

Name
summarize_design_area --Summarize cell area information of design.

Synopsis
summarize_design_area [-as_reference] [-with_delta] [-with_reference] [-recursive]

flag as_reference

flag recursive

flag with_delta

flag with_reference

Arguments
-as_reference Set current summary as a reference for later summary.

-recursive Report from top design as if all sub designs are flattened.

-with_delta Report delta to the reference if possible.

-with_reference Report the reference in the same table if exists.

Description
This command summarizes cell area information of design. It will output the cell count, area, and density
of design.

While the option -with_delta or -with_reference is on, it will try to find the matched reference record,
and report the difference according to the reference value of it. While option -as_reference is on, current
summary will be set as reference.

Examples
The following example summarizes the information of design area and set current summary as a reference
for later summary:

% summarize_design_area -as_reference
### design: SUB_MODULE ###
Count        Area    Density
-----------------------------
  378    6036.000    46.995%
### design: TOP_MODULE ###
Count         Area    Density
------------------------------
 1270    39023.360    46.529%
      

The following example summarizes the information of design area including all sub designs of the top
design:

% summarize_design_area -recursive -as_reference 
### design: TOP ###
Count         Area    Density
------------------------------
 2024    25407.360    30.294%
      

The following example summarizes the information of design area with previous reference and delta value:

% summarize_design_area -with_delta -with_reference 
### design: SUB_MODULE ###
Count  Count0  D_Count   Area  Area0  D_Area        Density  Density0  D_Density
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
210    378     -168    | 5011.00 6036.00 -1025.00 | 40.895% 46.995%  -6.100%
### design: TOP_MODULE ###
Count  Count0  D_Count   Area  Area0  D_Area       Density  Density0  D_Density
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1150   1270    -120    | 38978.24 39023.36 -45.12 | 46.476% 46.529%  -0.054%

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-as_reference Set current summary as a reference for later summary.

-current_hier_only Only report dynamic power information of cells in current hierachy.

Description
This command summarizes dynamic power for the specified modules or cells. It will print the cell count, dynamic power (including internal power and switching power).

Arguments
-with_delta Report delta to the reference if possible.

-with_reference Report also the reference if exists.

Description
If the option -with_delta or -with_reference is specified, it will try to find the matched reference record, and report the difference according to the reference value. If the option -as reference is specified, current summary will be set as reference.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
summarize_dynamic_power --Summarize dynamic power for the specified modules or cells.

Synopsis

int with_top_n in "[1,10000)"

collection cell_list
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-hier_path_list str_list Hier paths to summarize the dynamic power.

cell_list Cells to summarize the dynamic power.

Description
Please note cell_list and -hier_path_list are mutual exclusive options. If cell_list is specified, it will summarize cells in list. If -hier_path_list is specified, it will summarize modules in list. If both cell_list and -hier_path list are not specified, statistics of the whole design will be printed. If -cur_hier is given, only cells in this module level will be taken into account.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
summarize_dynamic_power --Summarize dynamic power for the specified modules or cells.

Synopsis

flag with_reference

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-with_top_n count Report also the top n dynamic power cells.

Description
If -with_top_n is specified, it will also print the information of top n dynamic power cells. There will be an upper bound 10000 for top n to avoid large size of report.

collection cell_list
knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example summarizes dynamic power for cells within the hier path list "A1", "A1/B3", "A1/ B3/C2".

%summarize_dynamic_power -hier_path_list {A1 A1/B3 A1/B3/C2} ### hier_path: A1 ### CellType           Count     Internal    Switching    DynamicPower ------------------------------------------------------------------ total                  8    4273.5104     705.9671       4979.4775   Sequential           1    3670.2777     101.9856       3772.2633   Combinational        7     603.2327     603.9815       1207.2142 ### hier_path: A1/B3 ### CellType           Count     Internal    Switching    DynamicPower ------------------------------------------------------------------ total                  8    4275.0508     336.1108       4611.1616   Sequential           1    3679.2404      76.0571       3755.2975   Combinational        7     595.8104     260.0537        855.8641 ### hier_path: A1/B3/C2 ### CellType           Count      Internal    Switching   DynamicPower ------------------------------------------------------------------ total                 10    11584.1675     315.0414     11899.2090   Sequential           3    10988.6548      77.2479     11065.9026   Combinational        7      595.5127     237.7936       833.3063       

The following example summarizes dynamic power for the whole design and set it as reference summary. Additionally, it will print top 3 dynamic power cells.

%summarize_dynamic_power -as_reference -with_top_n 3 ### design: fibre_ctrl ### CellType             Count      Internal     Switching    DynamicPower ---------------------------------------------------------------------- total              1503397    7.1552e+05    3.3095e+05    1.0465e+06   Sequential        254131    5.3892e+05    36583.6776    5.7551e+05   Combinational    1249266    1.7660e+05    2.9436e+05    4.7096e+05 ### top 3 cells ### Power       Internal    Switching    Name                                          -------------------------------------------- 419.5743    0.0000      419.5743     cell_A 408.7838    0.0000      408.7838     cell_B 408.7838    0.0000      408.7838     cell_C       

The follow example summarizes dynamic power after optimize_dynamic_power. Since -with_reference is specified, it will print both current and reference summary for convenience of comparison.

%summarize_dynamic_power -with_reference ### design: fibre_ctrl ### CellType             Count      Internal     Internal0      Switching  ... ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ... total              1503397    7.0662e+05    7.0745e+05  |  3.2754e+05    ...   Sequential        254131    5.3922e+05    5.3918e+05  |  36012.4054    ...   Combinational    1249266    1.6740e+05    1.6828e+05  |  2.9153e+05    ...

Commands

Name
summarize_eco_actions --Summarize eco actions and impact on designs.

Synopsis
summarize_eco_actions [-last_n count] [-recursive]

int last_n

flag recursive

Arguments
-last_n count The last n action to summarize, a number less than 1 means all.

-recursive Report from top design as if all sub designs are flattened.

Description
This command summarizes eco actions and impact on designs. It will report all the inserted, sized, and
removed cell count, corresponding delta area, and density. For hierarchical design, it reports every design
respectively by default. While option -recursive is specified, it will report the changes from top design as
if all sub designs are flattened.

Examples
The following example can summarize the last 5 steps of eco actions.

% summarize_eco_actions -last_n 5
### design: cpu ###
Name                  Count     D_Area    Density    D_Density
---------------------------------------------------------------
total                     -    +11.040    64.254%      +0.010%
  inserted                2    +12.960          -      +0.012%
    CKBUFD0BTH            1     +1.920          -      +0.002%
    BUFFD12BTH            1    +11.040          -      +0.010%
  sized                   2     +0.000          -      +0.000%
  removed                -1     -1.920          -      -0.002%
    CKBUFD1BTH           -1     -1.920          -      -0.002%
      

266

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-max_fanout val Setting max fanout threshold, for slack calculation, use parameter max_fanout if not specified.

-with_distribution Print a slack distribution histogram.

Description
This command summarizes the information of fanout violations in design. It will output the violation count, worst slack, and total negative slack, where slack is calculated by given max fanout threshold. If it is not set, value of parameter max_fanout will be used.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-io_only Only summarize those endpoints on io paths.

-r2r_only Only summarize those endpoints on r2r paths.

Description
By default, all pins are taken into account in the summary. Also you can summarize the violations related to io or internal r2r paths respectively by specifying option -io_only or -r2r_only. However, the criterion to identify whether a pin is on io or internal path is not well defined, and XTop just follows the timing data dumped from STA tools.

While option -exclude_dont_touch is specified, those endpoints that already marked as dont touch will be ignored in the summary. Notice that it only takes the dont touch attribute on pin, and does NOT care about cells and nets. If any doubt on this, please use command is_dont_touch to verify.

knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example summarizes the information of fanout violations on data path with default threshold:

% summarize_fanout_violations -data_path ### fanout summary ### Count         Worst           TNS ----------------------------------  1475    -64601.000    -1.432e+05       

The following example summarizes the information of fanout violations on both data and clock path and set current summary as a reference for later summary, with top 3 worst endpoints listed:

% summarize_fanout_violations -as_reference -max_fanout 64 \n                              -with_top_n 3 ### fanout summary ### Count         Worst           TNS ----------------------------------   579    -64569.000    -1.476e+05 ### fanout top 3 endpoints ###      Slack        Value    Constraint    Name
----------------------------------------------------- -64569.000    64633.000        64.000    UX_SCAN_EN -10631.000    10695.000        64.000    SPRSTB  -5615.000     5679.000        64.000    ECLK       

The following example summarizes the information of fanout violations with previous reference, where the new threshold is set to 128:

% summarize_fanout_violations -with_reference -max_fanout 128 ### fanout summary ### Count  Count0         Worst       Worst0         TNS          TNS0 ------------------------------------------------------------------   198     579    -64505.000   -64569.000  -1.260e+05    -1.476e+05

-with_top_n count Also report the top n worst endpoints.

Description
While -with_top_n is specified, it will display the information of top n violated endpoints. If a corresponding automatic fix flow has been applied, a statistical fail reason summary can also be displayed for each top n endpoint with option -with_fail_reason. Once -with_path_detail is specified, the summary of path list will be reported in detail format as those on GUI, and the data path timing of each path will be reported also. In the detail format, there will be an upper bound 10000 for top n to avoid large size of report.

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
summarize_inst_displacement --Summarize inst displacement information after optimization.

Synopsis
summarize_inst_displacement [-recursive] [-with_distribution] [-include_location] [- include_new_inst] [inst_list] [-with_top_n count]

flag include_location

flag include_new_inst

flag recursive

flag with_distribution

int with_top_n in "[1,inf)"

collection inst_list
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-include_location In the report, in each row, include the original and current location of the

instance.

-include_new_inst In the report, include newly-added instances' displacement information.

-recursive Report from top design as if all sub designs are flattened.

-with_distribution Print a distance distribution histogram.

-with_top_n count Set to report top N instances.

inst_list Instances Object to be honored.

Description
This command summarizes instances displacement information of design. It will output topN instances w.r.t. displacement. By default, it will report 3 items and report distance in micron and instance name at each row. Original and current location of the instances can be printed out by specifying -include_location. Especially for newly added instances, the distance stands for the distance between the point which user selected and the point which the tool finally choose to add.

% summarize_inst_displacement [get_cells -hierarchical U41*] ### design: regs ### Total count: 8 Max Cell Displacement(micron): 22.8954 Min Cell Displacement(micron): 5 Avg Cell Displacement(micron): 15.8561 Distance(micron)    Name               --------------------------------------- 22.8954             regs/dram1/C3/U417 22.8561             regs/dram1/C3/U415 22.1269             regs/dram1/C3/U418 ### design: cpu ### Total count: 1 Max Cell Displacement(micron): 2.2 Min Cell Displacement(micron): 2.2 Avg Cell Displacement(micron): 2.2 Distance(micron)    Name
------------------------- 2.2                 U414

% summarize_inst_displacement -recursive ### design: cpu ### Total count: 197 Max Cell Displacement(micron): 27.5804 Min Cell Displacement(micron): 0.2 Avg Cell Displacement(micron): 5.15338 Distance(micron)    Name               --------------------------------------- 27.5804             regs/dram1/C3/U471 22.8954             regs/dram1/C3/U417 22.8561             regs/dram1/C3/U415       

The following example summarizes the information of instance displacement for all design, list out its distance, instance name, original location, current location. Also it summarize the distance distribution at the end:

% summarize_inst_displacement -recursive -include_location -with_distribution ### design: cpu ### Total count: 197 Max Cell Displacement(micron): 27.5804 Min Cell Displacement(micron): 0.2 Avg Cell Displacement(micron): 5.15338 Distance(micron)    Name                  Original_location    Current_location -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 27.5804             regs/dram1/C3/U471    (138, 72.6)          (118.2, 91.8)    22.8954             regs/dram1/C3/U417    (131, 67.8)          (113.2, 53.4)    22.8561             regs/dram1/C3/U415    (125.2, 67.8)        (112.8, 87)

% ----------------------------------------------------------------------------  0.00 ~  3.00    #####################...................      103    52.3%  3.00 ~  6.00    #######.................................       35    17.8%  6.00 ~  9.00    ###.....................................       13     6.6%  9.00 ~ 12.00    ####....................................       19     9.6% 12.00 ~ 15.00    ##......................................        9     4.6% 15.00 ~ 18.00    ##......................................        8     4.1% 18.00 ~ 21.00    #.......................................        5     2.5% 21.00 ~ 24.00    #.......................................        4     2.0% 24.00 ~ 27.00    ........................................        0     0.0% 27.00 ~ 30.00    ........................................        1     0.5%

Commands

Name
summarize_leakage_power --Summarize leakage power for each keyword.

Synopsis
summarize_leakage_power [-as_reference] [-with_delta] [-with_reference] [-
include_physical_only] [-keywords str_list] [-recursive]

flag as_reference

flag include_physical_only

string_list keywords

flag recursive

flag with_delta

flag with_reference

Arguments
-as_reference Set current summary as a reference for later summary.

-include_physical_only Include physical only cells in the statistics.

-keywords str_list Keywords for classifying cells, use
eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords if it is empty or not specified.

-recursive Report from top design as if all sub designs are flattened.

-with_delta Report delta to the reference if possible.

-with_reference Report the reference in the same table if exists.

Description
This command summarizes leakage power for the specified keywords. It will output the cell count, leakage
power, and corresponding ratio.

While the option -with_delta or -with_reference is on, it will try to find the matched reference record,
and report the difference according to the reference value of it. While option -as_reference is on, current
summary will be set as reference.

By default, physical only cells are not take into account in the statistics unless option -
include_physical_only is specified.

Examples
The following example summarizes leakage power for cells with the keywords "ULVT", "LVT", "",
"HVT".

% summarize_leakage_power -keywords {ULVT LVT "" HVT}

### design: cpu ###
Keyword       Count       Ratio    LeakagePower
------------------------------------------------
total       1503403           -         180.6204
  ULVT            0     0.0000%           0.0000
  LVT         40916     2.7216%          35.7948
  HVT        151253    10.0607%           1.0282
  others    1311234    87.2177%         143.7974

Commands

Name
summarize_path_violations --Summarize the violation information of specified timing paths.

Synopsis
summarize_path_violations [-with_path_group] [-with_reference] [-with_delta] [-as_reference]
[-with_distribution] [ -with_top_n count [ -with_path_detail | -with_fail_reason ]] [path_list]

flag as_reference

flag with_delta

flag with_distribution

flag with_fail_reason

flag with_path_detail

flag with_path_group

flag with_reference

int with_top_n in "[1,inf)"

collection path_list

Arguments
-as_reference Set current summary as a reference for later summary.

-with_delta Report delta to the reference if possible.

-with_distribution Print a slack distribution histogram.

-with_fail_reason Report statistical summary of fail reasons on top n paths.

-with_path_detail Report path list and timing of every path in detail.

-with_path_group Report summary of path groups for each scenario.

-with_reference Report the reference in the same table if exists.

-with_top_n count Also report the top n worst paths or endpoints.

path_list Path list to summarize.

Description
This command summarizes the violation information of specified paths. It will output the violation count,
worst slack, total negative slack for all the paths and each scenario respectively. Those paths with slack
less than the unreasonable slack value unreasonable_negative_slack, or the corresponding scenario and
timing type is set as skipped will be ignored.

While the option -with_delta or -with_reference is on, it will try to find the matched reference record,
and report the difference according to the reference value of it. While option -as_reference is on, current
summary will be set as reference.

Once -with_top_n is specified, it will display the information of top n violated paths and endpoints. If a
corresponding automatic fix flow has been applied, a statistical fail reason summary can also be displayed
for each top n path with option -with_fail_reason. The summary of endpoints will be disabled under fail
reason mode.

Examples
The following example takes the current result as reference:

% summarize_path_violations -as_reference
      

After eco, you can get the delta value with the reference value.

% summarize_path_violations -with_delta -with reference
      

The following example shows the top 3 endpoints besides the summary.

% summarize_path_violations -with_top_n 3
      

280

This command summarizes the information of SI violations in design. It will output the violation count, worst slack, and total negative slack, where slack is calculated by given max SI threshold. The parameter -max_si specifies the limitation for delta delay caused by SI effect. The unit is ns, and parameter max_si will be used if this option is not specified.

While pins are specified, it will only summarize the pins in the pin list.

knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example summarizes the information of SI violations on data path with max si 0.05ns:

% summarize_si_violations -data_path -max_si 0.05 ### si summary ### Scenario            Count     Worst           TNS -------------------------------------------------- total              499084    -6.675    -13275.172   func_ff          144057    -1.327     -1593.994   func_ss          498985    -6.675    -13273.695       

The following example summarizes the information of SI violations on both data and clock path and set current summary as a reference for later summary, with top 3 worst endpoints listed, and set max_si to 0.2ns:

% summarize_si_violations -as_reference -max_si 0.2 \n                          -with_top_n 3 ### si summary ### Scenario           Count     Worst         TNS ----------------------------------------------- total               4196    -6.485    -579.571   func_ff            308    -1.137      -34.312   func_ss           4196    -6.485    -579.571 ### si top 3 endpoints ###  Slack    Scenario         Value    Constraint    Name
----------------------------------------------------------------- -6.485    func_ss          6.685         0.200    u_ctrl/U717/ZN -3.056    func_ss          3.256         0.200    u_ctrl/U7532/ZN -2.926    func_ss          3.126         0.200    u_ctrl/U30/ZN       

The following example summarizes the information of SI violations with previous reference, where the new max_si is set to 0.5ns:

% summarize_si_violations -with_reference -max_si 0.5 ### si summary ### Scenario  Count    Count0    Worst    Worst0       TNS        TNS0 ------------------------------------------------------------------ total       469     4196  | -6.185    -6.485  | -181.852    -579.571   func_ff    22      308  | -0.837    -1.137  | -3.301     -34.312   func_ss   469     4196  | -6.185    -6.485  | -181.852    -579.571

knowledge.summary:
Commands

Name
summarize_transition_violations --Summarize the information of transition violations in design.

Synopsis
summarize_transition_violations [-as_reference] [-with_delta] [-with_reference] [-clock] [-
data_path] [ -r2r_only | -io_only ] [-exclude_dont_touch] [-with_distribution] [ -with_top_n count [-
with_fail_reason]] [pin_list]

flag as_reference

flag clock

flag data_path

flag exclude_dont_touch

flag io_only

flag r2r_only

flag with_delta

flag with_distribution

flag with_fail_reason

flag with_reference

int with_top_n in "[1,inf)"

collection pin_list
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-as_reference Set current summary as a reference for later summary.

-clock Report violations on clock network.

-data_path Report violations on data path.

-exclude_dont_touch Do not take those pins marked as dont touch into account.

-io_only Only summarize those endpoints on io paths.

-r2r_only Only summarize those endpoints on r2r paths.

-with_delta Report delta to the reference if possible.

-with_distribution Print a slack distribution histogram.

-with_fail_reason Report fail reason on each top n pin.

-with_reference Report the reference in the same table if exists.

-with_top_n count Also report the top n worst endpoints.

pin_list Pins to summarize.

Description
This command summarizes the information of transition violations in design. It will output the violation
count, worst slack, and total negative slack.

The option -clock and -data_path represent the transition violations on clock network and data path
respectively. If none of them is specified, it acts as both of them are specified.

While the option -with_delta or -with_reference is on, it will try to find the matched reference record,
and report the difference according to the reference value of it. While option -as_reference is on, current
summary will be set as reference.

By default, all pins are taken into account in the summary. Also you can summarize the violations related
to io or internal r2r paths respectively by specifying option -io_only or -r2r_only. However, the criterion
to identify whether a pin is on io or internal path is not well defined, and XTop just follows the timing
data dumped from STA tools.

Once -with_top_n is specified, it will display the information of top n violated pins. If a corresponding
automatic fix flow has been applied, fail reasons can also be displayed for each top n pin with option -
with_fail_reason.

While option -exclude_dont_touch is specified, those endpoints that already marked as dont touch will be
ignored in the summary. Notice that it only takes the dont touch attribute on pin, and does NOT care about
cells and nets. If any doubt on this, please use command is_dont_touch to verify.

While pins are specified, it will only summarize the pins in the pin list.

and delta value:

Commands

Name
write_design_changes --Write out design changes that have been recorded in specified format.

Synopsis
write_design_changes [-format file_format] -eco_file_prefix file_name_prefix [- output_dir file_output_directory] [ -last_n output_command_count | -reorder ] [- exclude_new_created] [-keep_route] [ -write_atomic_cmd | -force ] [-add_on_route] [-version val]

flag add_on_route

string eco_file_prefix

flag exclude_new_created

flag force

enum format in "NATIVE INNOVUS CUI SOC ICC ICC2 PT ATOP V_DEF"

flag keep_route

int last_n

string output_dir

flag reorder

float version in "[0,inf)"

flag write_atomic_cmd
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-add_on_route Output add_buffer_on_route command for split net action in ICC2

format.

-eco_file_prefix file_name_prefix Prefix for eco files to write out netlist and physical changes.

-exclude_new_created Exclude new created instances when output physical changes.

-format file_format Output file format: NATIVE, INNOVUS, CUI, SOC, ICC, ICC2, PT, ATOP or V_DEF(experimental), default is INNOVUS.

-last_n output_command_count Write out the last N eco commands.

-output_dir file_output_directory Directory for eco files to write out.

-version val Output CUI commands for specified tool version.

Description
This command will write logical and physical changes for design into script files. For logical changes, option -last_n can be used to only output the changes of last N eco commands. For physical changes, it will always output all the changes. Currently formats for NATIVE, INNOVUS, CUI, SOC, ICC, ICC2, PT, ATOP and V_DEF(experimental) flows are supported. Especially for V_DEF(experimental), it writes out the design changes into an incremental def file(.def), and at the meantime, it writes out the whole current design into a verilog file(.v).

Commands

Name
write_design_changes --Write out design changes that have been recorded in specified format.

Synopsis

flag add_on_route

flag keep_route

int last_n

string output_dir

flag reorder

float version in "[0,inf)"

flag write_atomic_cmd
knowledge.content:
Arguments
-force Force to write out macro commands and only the illegal ones are written in atomic format.

-reorder Put the forced output commands at the end of the output sequence.

-write_atomic_cmd Write out atomic commands for each action.

Description
By default, macro commands will be output. However, it will report errors when following happens:
--Buffered pins are not in the same logic hierarchy when insert buffer or split net.
--Split net with inverter.
--Insert individual inverter when insert buffer chain.
--Insert AND/OR cell as buffer in post-mask eco.

In these cases, please write out atomic eco commands instead of macro commands with option -write_atomic_cmd. Or force to dump the macro commands with option -force. Here if -force option is used, atomic commands (which can be run by source command) will be dumped only for these particular actions. The atomic commands will be mixed with other macro commands. For some specific reasons, if these mixed commands are not convenient, please use -reorder option to put all the atomic commands at the end of the output sequence.

knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example writes out design changes in INNOVUS format to file with prefix "inno_macro".

% write_design_changes -eco_file_prefix inno_macro \n                       -format INNOVUS       

The following example writes out design changes in INNOVUS atomic command format to file with prefix "inno_atomic":

% write_design_changes -eco_file_prefix inno_atomic \n                       -format INNOVUS  -write_atomic_cmd       

The following example only writes out the last 5 eco commands in INNOVUS format.

% write_design_changes -eco_file_prefix inno_macro -last_n 5 \n                       -format INNOVUS       

The following example forces to write out the macro eco commands in INNOVUS format.

% write_design_changes -eco_file_prefix inno_macro \n                       -format INNOVUS -force       

The following example forces to write out the macro eco commands in CUI format and follow the 21.1 version.

% write_design_changes -eco_file_prefix macro \n                       -format CUI -force -version 21.1       

The following example writes out the design changes into the incremental def file and the whole current design into the verilog file.

% write_design_changes -eco_file_prefix macro \n                       -format V_DEF

Commands

Name
adjust_path_slack --To adjust path slack by change uncertainty value.

Synopsis
adjust_path_slack [ -target target | -offset change ] paths

float offset

float target

collection paths

Arguments
-offset change Slack change for given paths, unit is ns.

-target target Final slack value for given paths, unit is ns.

paths Paths to be adjusted, do nothing if not specified.

Description
This command adjusts path slack value. It will change path uncertainty value and related data. If no
uncertainty on path, then create it. Typically, clock uncertainty should be positive, so use this command
very carefully.

Two methods to adjust path slack : The final slack by -target. The slack change by -offset, the offset is
negative value when worsen path.

Examples
The following example specifies final slack for given paths.

% adjust_path_slack -target -0.05 [get_paths -end_points {RDATA15[1]} -delay_type max]
      

294

Commands

Name
analyze_leakage_keywords --Analyze leakage power and delay trend for cell nominal swap keywords
to guide leakage optimization.

Synopsis
analyze_leakage_keywords [-keywords name_list] [-group group_number]

int group in "[2,20]"

string_list keywords

Arguments
-group group_number Set the preferred keyword group number. At least 3 keywords are needed

if using this option. By default, two groups will be created.

-keywords name_list Keywords for swapping cells, use eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords if
not specified.

Description
This command analyze leakage power and delay trend for swap keywords to guide leakage optimization.
Keywords will be divided to several groups according to specified group number.

Some terminology on the reported results:

Slope : Delta leakage power divided by delta delay which represents the benefit change rate for adjacent
keywords. Delta leakage power and delta delay are calculated by the data of the adjacent keywords and
slope is marked on the preceding one.

Delta-Slope% : Delta slope ratio is delta slope divided by total slope span which represents the benefit
difference before and after a specific keyword. Delta slope is calculated by the slope marked on adjacent
keywords. Total slope span is the difference between the maximum and minimum slopes. Actually, delta
slope ratio is related to three adjacent keywords and marked on the middle one.

For simplicity, library cells in reference scenario are counted to get the average leakage power and delay
for each swap keyword. Slope and Delta-Slope% are calculated by average leakage and delay of adjacent
keywords.

As delta slope ratio represents the benefit difference before and after a specified keyword, break points to
divide the keyword groups are determined to be the keywords with the largest absolute delta slope ratios.

Generally speaking, more keyword groups bring better leakage optimization results. Optimization
iterations with minimum bubble keyword groups may bring the best result. However, large iteration
number may make runtime unacceptable. There is a trade-off between benefits and efficiency. So make
sure to give the appropriate group number when analyze and then optimize.

Examples
The following example shows how to analyze with keywords parameter and group option.

% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords \
                {"ULVT" "LVT" "" "HVT"}
% analyze_leakage_keywords -group 3
      

The following example shows how to analyze with keywords option.

% analyze_leakage_keywords -keywords {"ULVT" "LVT" "" "HVT"}
      

See Also
optimize_leakage_power

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-buffer clock_buffer Buffer or inverter used as the reference to increase or decrease

delay.

-count buffer_count The length of buffer chain used as a basic unit, default value is 1. If the specified library cell is inverter, this count should be inverter pair count instead.

-detail Print detail pin information in each scenario. If -target_pins is set and there is only one target pin, slack and margin data will be summarized for DADPins and BQPins. Note that the slack may be difference from the slack reported by report_pins command, because min path slack will be reported here if any path exists.

-hold The target is to fix hold violations.

-hold_wns_threshold This threshold is to prevent Hold timing WNS from getting worse. hold_wns_threshold

-honor_dont_touch Honor dont touch attribute of pin and net when analyze for eco candidates.

-include_begin_gain Calculate total gain ratio including begin gain.

-output_file output_file If output file is specified, analysis summary will dump to this file.

-scenario reference_scenario Referenced scenario to calculate gain.

-setup The target is to fix setup violations.

-setup_wns_threshold This threshold is to prevent Setup timing WNS from getting worse. setup_wns_threshold

-top count Report top n suggested results, default value is 50.

Description
Clock eco analysis will be performed by increasing or decreasing delay on some points. The delay change is measured by {buffer typical_delay * count} or {inverter typical_delay * 2 * count}. The early/late derate is not considered.

nBy default, it will increase delay on suggested eco points, and use insert_buffer or reconnect_net eco action to commit the solution.

By default, it will increase delay on suggested eco points, and use insert_buffer or reconnect_net eco action to commit the solution.

When it needs to reduce delay, please specify the -decrease_delay option, and use remove_buffer or reconnect_net to commit the solution.

Arguments
-target_pins target_pins Just analysis on those pins.

-trace_level trace_level Max allowed level for back trace when clock eco analysis, default value is 5.

Description
The default value of trace_level is 5, user can adjust it according to design situation.

NOTE: When specify target_pins, you should not set trace_level at the same time, and make sure there is no topology relation between target_pins. Tool only works fine for pins on clock tree, so no clock reconvergence or clock overlap. You can use hierarchical logic pin as target_pins.

knowledge.content:
Description
Some terminology on the reported results:
DACKPin : Directly affected CKPins, all fanout CKPins from eco point.
DADPin : Directly affected DPins, all related data pins of DACKPins.
BQPin : Begin QPins, all fanin QPins of DADPin.
TNS_Gain : Total negative slack gain on all DPins.
Begin_Gain : Total negative slack gain on all BQPins.
Margin_TNS_Gain : Total margin negative slack gain on all DPins.
TNS_Gain_Ratio : Total gain ratio on all DPins. It is calculated by {TNS_Gain / (buffer typical_delay * count)} or {TNS_Gain / (inverter typical_delay * 2 * count)}.
Begin_Gain_Ratio : Total gain ratio on all BQPins. It is calculated by {Begin_Gain / (buffer typical_delay * count)} or {Begin_Gain / (inverter typical_delay * 2 * count)}.
W_Margin_TNS_Gain_Ratio : Worst total margin gain ratio in multiple scenarios on all DPins. Total margin gain ratio is calculated by {Worst_Margin_TNS_Gain / (buffer typical_delay * count)} or {Worst_Margin_TNS_Gain / (inverter typical_delay * 2 * count)}.
Gain_Ratio : Total gain ratio synthesized TNS_Gain_Ratio, W_Margin_TNS_Gain_Ratio and Begin_Gain_Ratio. It is calculated by {TNS_Gain_Ratio + W_Margin_TNS_Gain_Ratio}. If include_begin_gain is set, the total gain ratio will be {TNS_Gain_Ratio + 0.1*Begin_Gain_Ratio + W_Margin_TNS_Gain_Ratio}.

The results will be sorted by total gain ratio. The concept of gain ratio is used as a criterion to filter the solutions. Once a buffer is inserted, the result expected is that it can bring a gain in a quantity of buffer delay without any negative effect. The TNS gain and impact can be then synthesized into a ratio of the expected buffer effect, the gain ratio.

Examples
The following example performs clock eco analysis for hold timing.

% clock_eco_analysis -buffer BUFF12 -hold

* No.  Gain_Ratio  TNS_Gain_Ratio  W_Margin_TNS_Gain_Ratio  Pin ********************************************************************************   1       161.952        279.952       -118.000      clk_gen_u0/gating_cell_u0/CP   2        56.000         56.000          0.000      U326/I   3        12.714         12.714          0.000      regs/dram2/U272/I       

The following example performs clock eco analysis for setup timing with decrease_delay.

% clock_eco_analysis -buffer BUFFD8 -setup -decrease_delay

* No.  Gain_Ratio  TNS_Gain_Ratio  W_Margin_TNS_Gain_Ratio  Pin ********************************************************************************   1       446.883        448.221         -1.338      SCIBUFXT1_G2B1I1_1/A   2       144.515        114.515          0.000      SCJFBUFCLXP1G1B1I39_2/A   3        73.224         73.224          0.000      SCJFBUFCLXP1G1B1I55_2/A       

See Also commit_clock_eco

Commands

Name
commit_clock_eco --Commit the solutions found by clock eco analysis.

Synopsis
commit_clock_eco [ -gain_ratio num | -top num ] { -setup | -hold }

int gain_ratio in "[1,inf)"

flag hold

flag setup

int top in "[1,1000]"

Arguments
-gain_ratio num Minimum gain ratio to filter solutions.

-hold Commit the solutions found by hold analysis.

-setup Commit the solutions found by setup analysis.

-top num Commit top n solutions of analysis.

Description
This command commits the solutions found by clock eco analysis. The analysis command lists the gain
and impact of each solutions in descending order of synthesized gain.

The concept of gain ratio is used as a criterion to filter the solutions. Once a buffer is inserted, the result
expected is that it can bring a gain in a quantity of buffer delay without any negative effect. The TNS gain
and impact can be then synthesized into a ratio of the expected buffer effect, the gain ratio. At the early
stage of optimization, a large gain ratio is commonly expected for clock eco. While in the later stage and
there is almost no solution on data paths, solutions with low gain ratio are also acceptable.

Anyway, for experienced designers, this command also supports to commit the top n solutions directly
with option "-top".

This command can only commit solutions of increasing delay mode. For decreasing delay mode, it needs
to convert the solution to a operational eco action and commit it manually.

Examples
The following example commits the top 10 hold-fix solutions found by clock eco analysis.

% commit_clock_eco -hold -top 10
      

See Also
clock_eco_analysis

302

Commands

Name
enlarge_timing_violations --Enlarge specified timing violations, only for GBA mode.

Synopsis
enlarge_timing_violations [ -setup | -hold ] [-scenarios patterns] factor

flag hold

string_list scenarios

flag setup

float factor in "(0.1,10)"

Arguments
-hold Enlarge hold violations.

-scenarios patterns Scenarios to enlarge the violations, matched by wildcard.

-setup Enlarge setup violations.

factor The factor to multiply with negative slack.

Description
This command enlarges the timing violations, only for GBA mode. It will multiply the negative slack with
the specified factor. If no hold or setup flag specified, both setup and hold violations will be enlarged.
Violations of all scenarios will be modified unless scenarios are specified.

Here the word "enlarge" acts just like "scale" except that it gives a hint that you should enlarge the
violations to get a better result for most cases. However, it is not prohibited to specify a factor less than
1.0 to shrink the violations if you do want to do that.

Examples
The following example specifies a factor to enlarge the hold timing violations.

% enlarge_timing_violations -hold 1.1

This command exports the specified clock eco solutions as commands for third party STA tools. Only
increasing delay mode and insert buffer is supported. All scripts exported are based on top design.

Description
This command fixes capacitance violations in design.

Once the fix process finished, it will report the gain obtained, area and density variations. If the violations are not completely fixed, the statistics of fail reasons will also be reported. Thus, you can change the policy or release more resources according to these reasons. The command report_fail_reasons can help to review the detail reasons on specified objects.

This command returns the number of solutions committed.

Arguments
-methods method_list Methods used to fix capacitance, can be any combination of insert_buffer, size_cell, and split_net, all enabled by default.

Description
It will try to size cell, insert buffer, and split net by default, and choose the best one from them.

When using split net, tool will try best to satisfy the constraint by target and margin. There is an internal limit which do not allow split exhaustively, caused by unrealistic target and margin.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-capacitance_margin margin_val Capacitance slack margin to be reserved with unit pF, use eco_capacitance_slack_margin if not specified.

-capacitance_target slack_val Target of capacitance slack with unit pF, use eco_capacitance_slack_target if not specified.

-transition_margin margin_val Transition slack margin to be reserved with unit ns, use eco_transition_slack_margin if not specified.

-rel_transition_margin Relative transition slack margin to be reserved with rel_margin_val the value of percentage to max transition, use eco_relative_transition_slack_margin if not specified, a sum of transition_margin and rel_transition_margin will be actually used.

Description
By default, this command will try to fix the violations to slack greater than 0, and will not break the max transition constraint, and max capacitance constraint of those nets that affected by this eco action indirectly. Commonly, this is enough since the algorithm is always a little pessimistic. However, if you really concerned about the effect and there are enough resources in the design, you can over-fix it by adding a positive target, and over-constraint the transition, capacitance by adding a positive margin with option -capacitance_target, -transition_margin and -capacitance_margin respectively.

If the target and margins are not specified, corresponding parameters eco_capacitance_slack_target, eco_transition_slack_margin, and eco_capacitance_slack_margin will be used as default.

However, the impact will be considered together with the area cost, and the capacitance gain, and will be optimized as small as possible. We also offer an option -check_timing_margin to add extra margin check if user do not want to break any timing margin, but solution may be less if this option specified.

knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example uses size cell and insert buffer methods to fix capacitance violations.

% fix_capacitance_violations -methods {size_cell insert_buffer}       

The following example fix capacitance violations only size DFF cells.

% fix_capacitance_violations -methods {size_cell} -dff_only       

The following example only fixes capacitance violations on clock path.

% fix_capacitance_violations -on_clock       

The following example over-fixes capacitance violations to 0.02pF.

% fix_capacitance_violations -capacitance_target 0.02       

The following example over-constraints the transition and capacitance by 0.01ns and 0.01pF respectively.

% fix_capacitance_violations -transition_margin 0.01 \n                             -capacitance_margin 0.01       

The following example uses nominal keywords defined in parameter eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords for swapping cells to fix capacitance violations.

% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords \n                "lvt@n30 nvt@n40 hvt@n40"
% fix_capacitance_violations -size_rule nominal_keywords       

The following example only fixes capacitance violations on pin U316/Z and U395/Z, and also check timing margin.

% fix_capacitance_violations {U316/Z U395/Z} -check_timing_margin       

See Also fix_transition_violations fix_setup_path_violations fix_hold_path_violations

Commands

Name
fix_fanout_violations --Fix fanout violations in design.

Synopsis
int fix_fanout_violations [-buffer_list buffer_inverter_names] [-max_fanout
threshold] [-on_clock] [-disable_report] [violations] [-debug_pins pin_list]

collection buffer_list

collection debug_pins

flag disable_report

int max_fanout in "[4,inf)"

flag on_clock

collection violations

Arguments
-buffer_list buffer_inverter_names Buffers/Inverters used to fix fanout violations, use buffers/inverters

defined in eco_buffer_list_for_setup if not specified.

-debug_pins pin_list XTop will print more debug log for specified pins, and abort fix
once all these pins have been scanned.

-disable_report Do NOT generate a report of violation and fail reason in workspace.

-max_fanout threshold Max fanout threshold, use parameter max_fanout if not specified.

-on_clock Fix violations on clock only.

violations The violations of pins to fix, all if not specified.

Description
This command fixes fanout violations in design. It will try to split net, to keep fanout number not exceed
the max fanout threshold defined by user. If this option is not set, it will use the value of max_fanout.

Once the fix process finished, it will report the solution number, area increased, and statistics of fail reason
if violations are not fully fixed.

By default, a report of violations and fail reasons is generated under the directory opt in workspace.
The maximum violation count is limited to 10000 since it will be time consuming if there are plenty of
violations remained. Option -disable_report can be used to avoid generating this report.

This command also supports to fix specific violations by specifying a collection of violated pins. The
summary and fail reason are also limited to specified pins.

When violated pins are specified by user, tool will automatically expand all the mirror pins of them.

This command returns the number of solutions committed.

Examples
The following example fix max fanout violations.

% fix_fanout_violations -max_fanout 16 -buffer_list {BUF01 BUF03}
      

The following example fix max fanout violations on clock only.

% fix_fanout_violations -on_clock -buffer_list {BUF01 BUF03}
      

The following example fix max fanout violations on pin mul137/ZN.

% fix_fanout_violations {mul137/ZN}
      

See Also
fix_wire_length_violations

knowledge.content:
Arguments
violations The violations of pins to fix, all if not specified.

Description
This command also supports to fix specific violations by specifying a collection of violated pins. In XTop, the violations on the whole net is considered even only part of the sinks are specified. So, once a pin is specified, all the pins of the net will be taken into account. The timing summary and fail reason are also limited to pins on the nets.

When violated pins are specified by user, tool will automatically expand all the mirror pins of them.

knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example fix glitch violations using split_net only.

% fix_glitch_violations -buffer_list {BUF01 BUF03} -methods {split_net}        

The following example fix glitch violations using size_cell and cell_attribute as sizing rule.

% set_parameter eco_cell_classify_rule cell_attribute
% fix_glitch_violations -methods {size_cell}       

The following example fix glitch violations using size_cell for DFF only.

% fix_glitch_violations -methods {size_cell} -dff_only       

The following example fix glitch violations using both split_net and size_cell on clock.

% fix_glitch_violations -buffer_list {BUF01 BUF03} -on_clock       

The following example fix glitch violations while setting min split wire length to 50um.

% fix_glitch_violations -methods {split_net} -wire_length_threshold 50       

See Also fix_fanout_violations fix_wire_length_violations fix_transition_violations

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-buffer_list buffer_names Buffers used to fix violations, use eco_buffer_list_for_hold if not

specified.

-capacitance_margin margin_val Capacitance slack margin to be reserved with unit pF, use eco_capacitance_slack_margin if not specified.

-debug_pins pin_list XTop will print more debug log for specified pins, and abort fix once all these pins have been scanned.

-delay_cell_list delay_cell_names Delay buffer list to specify delay buffer.

-dff_only Only size dff (reg) cells when set. If not specified, only size comb cells. Suggest only swapping cells using nominal_keywords.

-effort effort_level Effort level in optimization, default is low.

-group If group target pins according to interconnection and take pins in proportion for each iteration.

-hold_target slack_val Target of hold slack with unit ns, use eco_hold_slack_target if not specified.

wants to use this feature.

-rel_transition_margin Relative transition slack margin to be reserved with rel_margin_val the value of percentage to max transition, use

eco_relative_transition_slack_margin if not specified, a sum of transition_margin and rel_transition_margin will be actually used.

-setup_margin margin_val Setup slack margin to be reserved with unit ns, use eco_setup_slack_margin if not specified.

-size_cell_only Size cell only to fix hold, and only size down.

-size_rule rule_type Indicate the rule used to find candidates for sizing cells, use eco_cell_classify_rule if not specified.

-summarize_internal_iteration Summarize each internal iteration.

-transition_margin margin_val Transition slack margin to be reserved with unit ns, use eco_transition_slack_margin if not specified.

Description
This command fixes hold GBA violations. For any pins, if there are paths through it, it will use the worst slack of paths instead of GBA slack. Generally, it is recommended to only fix violations on paths since GBA values are always pessimistic and will be over-fixed. But paths cannot cover all the violations, and it needs iterations to fix all the violations. If the concern is the completion rate, and the cost of over-fix is not that important, you can try this command.

For detail, please refer to fix_hold_path_violations. If you want to allow breaking setup after optimization, you can set the setup margin to a negative value.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
violations The violations of pins to fix, all if not specified.

Description
This command also supports to fix specific violations by specifying a collection of violated pins (endpoints). While the collection of violation is specified, all fan in and fan out pins will be traced to form a sub graph to search solutions. The timing summary of timing and fail reason are also limited to the traced sub graph.

When violations or pins are specified by user, tool will automatically expand all the mirror pins of them. However, if the endpoint violations is less than unreasonable_negative_slack, the endpoint will be ignored and not fixed.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-max_cluster_loader_count Max loader number that can be clustered to one group, default is max_count 1, means the function is disabled. 4 is the suggested value if user

Description
We also provide an option -max_cluster_loader_count, to enable/disable cluster loader function, try to reduce buffer count, and also improve fix result. This feature is suggested to turn on if user find buffer count is not optimized as expect. It is the limit of how many loaders can be clustered for inserting buffer. The option is 1 by default, means the function is disabled. When enabled, tool will first try to put similar violated loaders into one group under the constraint of max_cluster_loader_count, and insert buffer for it in one step. If the loaders can not be clustered, or not totally fixed, tool will then try insert buffer for each unfixed loader one by one, like default behavior. Note that tool does not always cluster loader at max_cluster_loader_count, but clustering according to practical situation.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-fix_timing_window Also fix timing window while fix hold violations, not work with -size_cell_only and when -effort is not low. Suggest using this feature if many break setup fail reasons are found in summary.

Description
When the option -fix_timing_window is specified, tool will try to size a few driver cells on the path of the pins which setup margin are always broken, so there's a chance to get a better setup margin after sizing. User can set size cell parameter, like eco_cell_classify_rule, or eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords, and so on, to control sizing behavior. In next step, tool will try to fix hold violation again, so a better fix result is expected.

If no dummy cell can fix, insert buffer will be automatically tried next. Meanwhile, -dummy_only can be set to only allow add dummy cell.

knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example fixes hold gba violations with effort high.

% fix_hold_gba_violations -effort high       

The following example fixes hold gba violations using buffers in buffer list.

% fix_hold_gba_violations -buffer_list "DLY01 DLY02 DLY04"       

The following example fixes hold gba violations with hold target 0.005ns and setup margin 0.005ns.

% set_parameter eco_hold_slack_target 0.005
% set_parameter eco_setup_slack_margin 0.005
% fix_hold_gba_violations       

The following example shows how to overwrite the hold target and setup margin to 0 and 0.01ns in this commands.

% set_parameter eco_hold_slack_target 0.005
% set_parameter eco_setup_slack_margin 0.005
% fix_hold_gba_violations -setup_margin 0.01 -hold_target 0       

The following example fixes hold gba violations by size_cell only.

% fix_hold_gba_violations -size_cell_only       

The following example fixes hold gba violations by swap VT cells honoring following keywords rules.

% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords \n                {"ULVT" "LVT" "" "HVT"}
% fix_hold_gba_violations -size_cell_only \n                          -size_rule nominal_keywords       

The following example fixes hold gba violations by size_cell honoring following regular expression rules.

% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_sizing_pattern {"X[0-9]+TH"}
% fix_hold_gba_violations -size_cell_only -size_rule nominal_regex       

The following example fixes hold gba violations by insert buffer for max 3 clustered loaders.

% fix_hold_gba_violations -buffer_list "DLY01 DLY02 DLY04"                            -max_cluster_loader_count 3        The following example fixes hold gba violations, and uses nominal_keywords to swap cell when fix timing window.

% set_parameter eco_cell_classify_rule nominal_keywords
% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords {"HVT" "" "LVT"}
% fix_hold_gba_violations -buffer_list "DLY01" -fix_timing_window       

The following example fix hold gba violations only using insert dummy cell.

% set_parameter eco_dummy_cell_list_for_hold {BUF02}
% fix_hold_gba_violations -use_dummy_cell -dummy_only       

The following example fix hold gba violations using insert buffer as well as insert dummy cell.

% set_parameter eco_dummy_cell_list_for_hold {BUF02}
% fix_hold_gba_violations -buffer_list "BUF01 BUF02 DLY01" -use_dummy_cell       

The following example fix hold gba violation by setting max_delay_cell_length to 3.

% fix_hold_gba_violations -buffer_list "BUF01 DLY01 DEL02"           -max_delay_cell_length 3 -delay_cell_list [get_lib_cells {DEL* DLY*}]       

See Also fix_hold_path_violations fix_setup_gba_violations

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-buffer_list buffer_names Buffers used to fix violations, use eco_buffer_list_for_hold if not specified.

-debug_pins pin_list XTop will print more debug log for specified pins, and abort fix once all these pins have been scanned.

-delay_cell_list delay_cell_names Delay cell list to specify delay buffer.

-dff_only Only size dff cells (D flip-flop cells) when set. If not specified, only size comb cells. Suggest only swapping cells using nominal_keywords.

-only_pins pin_list Only generate solutions on the specified pins if specified.

paths Paths to fix hold violations, all if not specified.

Description
This command fixes hold violations of the specified paths, if the paths are not specified, it will fix all the violated hold paths. Those paths (including its endpoint) with slack (hold violation) less than the unreasonable slack value unreasonable_negative_slack , or the corresponding scenario and timing type is set as skipped will be ignored. Once the fix process finished, it will report the gain obtained, area and density variations.

If the violations are not completely fixed, the statistics of fail reasons will also be reported. Thus, you can change the policy or release more resources according to these reasons. The command report_fail_reasons can help to review the detail reasons on specified objects.

This command returns the number of solutions committed.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-capacitance_margin margin_val Capacitance slack margin to be reserved with unit pF, use eco_capacitance_slack_margin if not specified.

-hold_target slack_val Target of hold slack of this optimization action with unit ns, use eco_hold_slack_target if not specified.

-setup_margin margin_val Setup slack margin to be reserved with unit ns, use eco_setup_slack_margin if not specified.

-transition_margin margin_val Transition slack margin to be reserved with unit ns, use eco_transition_slack_margin if not specified.

-rel_transition_margin Relative transition slack margin to be reserved with rel_margin_val the value of percentage to max transition, use eco_relative_transition_slack_margin if not specified, a sum of transition_margin and rel_transition_margin will be actually used.

Description
By default, this command will try to fix the violated paths to slack greater than 0, and will not break the setup, max transition, and max capacitance, or not to make them worse if there is already a violation. Commonly, this is enough since the algorithm is always a little pessimistic. However, if you really concerned about the effect and there are enough resources in the design, you can over-fix it by adding a positive target, and over-constraint the setup, transition, capacitance by adding a positive margin with option -hold_target, -setup_margin, -transition_margin and -capacitance_margin respectively. If you want to allow breaking setup after optimization, you can set the setup margin to a negative value. If the target and margins are not specified, corresponding parameters eco_hold_slack_target, eco_setup_slack_margin, eco_transition_slack_margin, and eco_capacitance_slack_margin will be used as default.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-size_rule rule_type Indicate the rule used to find candidates for sizing cells, use eco_cell_classify_rule if not specified.

-size_cell_only Size cell only to fix hold, and only size down.

Description
The most efficient method to fix hold is to insert buffer chain. To keep the consistency, the buffers can only be inserted at the sinks of net, and there is a limitation eco_max_buffer_chain_length on the number of buffers inserted at one pin. Another way to fix hold is to size cells, and it only allows to size down here. It is recommended that to fix hold by sizing cells before inserting buffers since there is no area cost, and on the contrary, it can release some die area. While size cell is used, the candidates are searched in groups classified by the rule of option -size_rule. If this option is not specified, eco_cell_classify_rule will be used as default. User can set size cell parameter, like eco_cell_classify_rule, or eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords, and so on, to control sizing behavior. In next step, tool will try to fix hold violation again, so a better fix result is expect.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-effort effort_level Effort level in optimization, default is low.

-summarize_internal_iteration Summarize each internal iteration.

Description
The option -effort controls the count of internal optimization iterations. The pins will be sorted by the violations they covered and classified into groups with different priorities. The higher effort level, the more groups will be classified. As a cost, more CPU time will be consumed in the optimization process. Generally, it will result in a better optimization quality with higher effort. However, this depends on the timing status, placement and routing density of the design. Sometimes, the last iteration will be inefficient, and waste a lot of die area. The option -summarize_internal_iteration can be turned on to review the effect of each internal iteration.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-max_cluster_loader_count Max loader number that can be clustered to one group, default is max_count 1, means the function is disabled. 4 is the suggested value if user wants to use this feature.

Description
We also provide an option -max_cluster_loader_count, to enable/disable cluster loader function, try to reduce buffer count, and also improve fix result. This feature is suggested to turn on if user find buffer count is not optimized as expect. It is the limit of how many loaders can be clustered for inserting buffer. The option is 1 by default, means the function is disabled. When enabled, tool will first try to put similar violated loaders into one group under the constraint of max_cluster_loader_count, and insert buffer for it in one step. If the loaders can not be clustered, or not totally fixed, tool will then try insert buffer for each unfixed loader one by one, like default behavior. Note that tool does not always cluster loader at max_cluster_loader_count, but clustering according to practical situation.

knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example fixes hold path violations with effort high.

% fix_hold_path_violations -effort high       

The following example fixes hold path violations with buffers defined in buffer_list, and the max buffer chain's lengths is 5.

% set_parameter eco_max_buffer_chain_length 5
% fix_hold_path_violations -buffer_list "DLY01 DLY02 DLY04"       

The following example fixes hold path violations with hold target 0.005ns and setup margin 0.005ns.

% set_parameter eco_hold_slack_target 0.005
% set_parameter eco_setup_slack_margin 0.005
% fix_hold_path_violations       

The following example shows how to overwrite the hold target and setup margin to 0 and 0.01ns in this commands.

% set_parameter eco_hold_slack_target 0.005
% set_parameter eco_setup_slack_margin 0.005
% fix_hold_path_violations -setup_margin 0.01 -hold_target 0       

The following example fixes hold violations only on specified paths.

% fix_hold_path_violations [get_paths -delay_type min \n                           -lower_bound -1.000 -upper_bound 0.000]        The following example fixes hold path violations by size_cell only.

% fix_hold_path_violations -size_cell_only       

The following example fixes hold path violations by swap VT cells honoring following keywords rule.

% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords \n                {"ULVT" "LVT" "" "HVT"}
% fix_hold_path_violations -size_cell_only \n                           -size_rule nominal_keywords       

The following example fixes hold path violations by size_cell honoring following regular expression rule.

% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_sizing_pattern {"X[0-9]+TH"}
% fix_hold_path_violations -size_cell_only -size_rule nominal_regex       

The following example fixes hold path violations by insert buffer for max 3 clustered loaders.

% fix_hold_path_violations -buffer_list "DLY01 DLY02 DLY04"                            -max_cluster_loader_count 3       

The following example fixes hold path violations, and uses cell_attribute as sizing rule to fix timing window.

% set_parameter eco_cell_classify_rule cell_attribute
% fix_hold_path_violations -buffer_list "DLY01" -fix_timing_window       

The following example fix hold path violations only using insert dummy cell.

% set_parameter eco_dummy_cell_list_for_hold {BUF02}
% fix_hold_path_violations -use_dummy_cell -dummy_only       

The following example fix hold path violations using insert buffer as well as insert dummy cell.

% set_parameter eco_dummy_cell_list_for_hold {BUF02}
% fix_hold_path_violations -buffer_list "BUF01 BUF02 DLY01" -use_dummy_cell       

The following example fix hold path violation by setting max_delay_cell_length to 3.

% fix_hold_path_violations -buffer_list "BUF01 DLY01 DEL02"           -max_delay_cell_length 3 -delay_cell_list [get_lib_cells {DEL* DLY*}]       

See Also fix_hold_gba_violations fix_setup_path_violations

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-buffer_list buffer_names Buffers used to fix violations, use eco_buffer_list_for_setup if not specified.

-capacitance_margin margin_val Capacitance slack margin to be reserved with unit pF, use eco_capacitance_slack_margin if not specified.

-debug_pins pin_list XTop will print more debug log for specified pins, and abort fix once all these pins have been scanned.

-dff_only Only size dff (reg) cells when set. If not specified, only size comb cells. Suggest only swapping cells using nominal_keywords. It works with size cell alone.

-effort effort_level Effort level in optimization, default is low.

-enable_multithread Enable multi-thread sizing comb cells. This function is disabled when use debug_pins or only_pins.

-group If group target pins according to interconnection and take pins in proportion for each iteration.

-hold_margin margin_val Hold slack margin to be reserved with unit ns, use eco_hold_slack_margin if not specified.

-methods method_list Methods used to fix setup, can be any combination of insert_buffer, size_cell, and split_net, default use insert_buffer and size_cell.

-priority_weight type_name Priority weight to classify pins, for debugging purpose.

-rel_transition_margin Relative transition slack margin to be reserved with rel_margin_val the value of percentage to max transition, use

eco_relative_transition_slack_margin if not specified, a sum of transition_margin and rel_transition_margin will be actually used.

-remove_buffer_only Remove buffer only to fix setup.

-setup_target slack_val Target of setup slack with unit ns, use eco_setup_slack_target if not specified.

-size_rule rule_type Indicate the rule used to find candidates for sizing cells, use eco_cell_classify_rule if not specified.

-summarize_internal_iteration Summarize each internal iteration.

-transition_margin margin_val Transition slack margin to be reserved with unit ns, use eco_transition_slack_margin if not specified.

Description
This command fixes setup GBA violations. For any pins, if there are paths through it, it will use the worst slack of paths instead of GBA slack. Generally, it is recommended to only fix violations on paths since GBA values are always pessimistic and will be over-fixed. But paths cannot cover all the violations, and it needs iterations to fix all the violations. If the concern is the completion rate, and the cost of over-fix is not that important, you can try this command.

For detail, please refer to fix_setup_path_violations.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-only_pins pin_list Only generate solutions on specified pins if specified.

violations The violations of pins to fix, all if not specified.

Description
This command also supports to fix specific violations by specifying a collection of violated pins (endpoints). While the collection of violation is specified, all fan in and fan out pins will be traced to form a sub graph to search solutions. The timing summary of timing and fail reason are also limited to the traced sub graph.

Another option -only_pins specifies the pins that solutions can be generated on. While this options is specified, it behaves like that all the other pins are marked as dont touch. However, if the endpoint violations is less than unreasonable_negative_slack, the endpoint will be ignored and not fixed.

knowledge.content:
Examples
The following example fixes setup gba violations with effort high.

% fix_setup_gba_violations -effort high       

The following example fixes setup gba violations using remove_buffer methods.

% fix_setup_gba_violations -remove_buffer_only       

The following example fixes setup gba violations using size_cell only.

% fix_setup_gba_violations -methods "size_cell"       

The following example fixes setup gba violations using both size_cell and split_net.

% fix_setup_gba_violations -methods "size_cell split_net"       

The following example fixes setup path violations using size_cell only and candidates area ratio is constrained to 3.0.

% set_parameter eco_size_cell_area_change_ratio 3.0
% fix_setup_path_violations -methods "size_cell"       

The following example fixes setup gba violations by size_cell honoring following keywords rule.

% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_swap_keywords \n                {"ULVT" "LVT" "" "HVT"}
% fix_setup_gba_violations -methods "size_cell" \n                           -size_rule nominal_keywords       

The following example fixes setup gba violations by size_cell honoring following regular expression rule.

% set_parameter eco_cell_nominal_sizing_pattern {X([0-9]+)TH}
% fix_setup_gba_violations -size_rule nominal_regex \n                           -methods size_cell       

The following example fixes setup gba violations with setup target 0.005ns and hold margin -0.005ns.

% set_parameter eco_setup_slack_target 0.005
% set_parameter eco_hold_slack_margin -0.005
% fix_setup_gba_violations       

The following example shows how to overwrite the setup target and hold margin to 0 and -0.01ns in this commands.

% set_parameter eco_setup_slack_target 0.005
% set_parameter eco_hold_slack_margin -0.005
% fix_setup_gba_violations -setup_target 0 -hold_margin -0.01     

See Also fix_setup_path_violations fix_hold_gba_violations

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-buffer_list buffer_names Buffers used to fix violations, use eco_buffer_list_for_setup if not specified.

-debug_pins pin_list XTop will print more debug log for specified pins, and abort fix once all these pins have been scanned.

-dff_only Only size dff (reg) cells when set. If not specified, only size comb cells. Suggest only swapping cells using nominal_keywords. It works with size cell alone.

-enable_multithread Enable multi-thread sizing comb cells. This function is disabled when use debug_pins or only_pins.

-only_pins pin_list Only generate solutions on specified pins if specified.

-priority_weight type_name Priority weight to classify pins, for debugging purpose.

paths Paths to fix setup violations, all if not specified.

Description
This command fixes setup violations of the specified paths, if the paths are not specified, it will fix all the violated setup paths. Those paths with slack less than the unreasonable slack value unreasonable_negative_slack, or the corresponding scenario and timing type is set as skipped will be ignored.

Once the fix process finished, it will report the gain obtained, area and density variations. If the violations are not completely fixed, the statistics of fail reasons will also be reported. Thus, you can change the policy or release more resources according to these reasons. The command report_fail_reasons can help to review the detail reasons on specified objects.

This command returns the number of solutions committed.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-capacitance_margin margin_val Capacitance slack margin to be reserved with unit pF, use eco_capacitance_slack_margin if not specified.

-hold_margin margin_val Hold slack margin to be reserved with unit ns, use eco_hold_slack_margin if not specified.

-setup_target slack_val Target of setup slack with unit ns, use eco_setup_slack_target if not specified.

-transition_margin margin_val Transition slack margin to be reserved with unit ns, use eco_transition_slack_margin if not specified.

-rel_transition_margin Relative transition slack margin to be reserved with rel_margin_val the value of percentage to max transition, use

eco_relative_transition_slack_margin if not specified, a sum of transition_margin and rel_transition_margin will be actually used.

Description
By default, this command will try to fix the violated paths to slack greater than 0, and will not break the hold, max transition, and max capacitance, or not to make them worse if there is already a violation. Commonly, this is enough since the algorithm is always a little pessimistic. However, if you really concerned about the effect and there are enough resources in the design, you can over-fix it by adding a positive target, and over-constraint the hold, transition, capacitance by adding a positive margin with option -setup_target, -hold_margin, -transition_margin and -capacitance_margin respectively. If the target and margins are not specified, corresponding parameters eco_hold_slack_target, eco_hold_slack_margin, eco_transition_slack_margin, and eco_capacitance_slack_margin will be used as default.

knowledge.content:
Arguments
-methods method_list Methods used to fix setup, can be any combination of insert_buffer, size_cell, and split_net, default use insert_buffer and size_cell.

Description
By default, this command uses size cell and insert buffer method, user can also specify split net for each scan pin, and XTop will choose the best solution among them. While sizing cells, the buffers are different from common cells. There exists a special type: delay buffer for most libraries, and commonly they have different footprint with common buffers. If cells are classified with cell footprint, they cannot be classified into the same group with common buffers, and of course, they can not be sized to common buffers. To avoid this issue, you can build a buffer group by defining parameter eco_buffer_group.

When fix setup path violation by size cell, we can use eco_size_cell_area_change_ratio to limit area change, it is 6.0 if not specified.

Arguments
-remove_buffer_only Remove buffer only to fix setup.

Description
Remove buffer is a special method for fixing setup violations. It is especially effective for those setup violations caused by buffer chains inserted by synthesis or placement and routing tools. It is recommended to run a separate iteration of removing buffer before any other methods.
